t: Genesis 1
In*p the beginning God created the heaven and the earth.
And*p the earth was without form, and void; and darkness was upon the face of the deep. And the Spirit of God moved upon the face of the waters.
And*p God said, Let there be light: and there was light.
And*p God saw the light, that it was good: and God divided the light from the darkness.
And*p God called the light Day, and the darkness he called Night. And the evening and the morning were the first day.
And*p God said, Let there be a firmament in the midst of the waters, and let it divide the waters from the waters.
And*p God made the firmament, and divided the waters which were under the firmament from the waters which were above the firmament: and it was so.
And*p God called the firmament Heaven. And the evening and the morning were the second day.
And*p God said, Let the waters under the heaven be gathered together unto one place, and let the dry land appear: and it was so.
And*p God called the dry land Earth; and the gathering together of the waters called he Seas: and God saw that it was good.
And*p God said, Let the earth bring forth grass, the herb yielding seed, and the fruit tree yielding fruit after his kind, whose seed is in itself, upon the earth: and it was so.
And*p the earth brought forth grass, and herb yielding seed after his kind, and the tree yielding fruit, whose seed was in itself, after his kind: and God saw that it was good.
And*p the evening and the morning were the third day.
And*p God said, Let there be lights in the firmament of the heaven to divide the day from the night; and let them be for signs, and for seasons, and for days, and years:
And*p let them be for lights in the firmament of the heaven to give light upon the earth: and it was so.
And*p God made two great lights; the greater light to rule the day, and the lesser light to rule the night: he made the stars also.
And*p God set them in the firmament of the heaven to give light upon the earth,
And*p to rule over the day and over the night, and to divide the light from the darkness: and God saw that it was good.
And*p the evening and the morning were the fourth day.
And*p God said, Let the waters bring forth abundantly the moving creature that hath life, and fowl that may fly above the earth in the open firmament of heaven.
And*p God created great whales, and every living creature that moveth, which the waters brought forth abundantly, after their kind, and every winged fowl after his kind: and God saw that it was good.
And*p God blessed them, saying, Be fruitful, and multiply, and fill the waters in the seas, and let fowl multiply in the earth.
And*p the evening and the morning were the fifth day.
And*p God said, Let the earth bring forth the living creature after his kind, cattle, and creeping thing, and beast of the earth after his kind: and it was so.
And*p God made the beast of the earth after his kind, and cattle after their kind, and every thing that creepeth upon the earth after his kind: and God saw that it was good.

And*p God said, Let us make man in our image, after our likeness: and let them have dominion over the fish of the sea, and over the fowl of the air, and over the cattle, and over all the earth, and over every creeping thing that creepeth upon the earth.
So*p God created man in his own image, in the image of God created he him; male and female created he them.

And*p God blessed them, and God said unto them, Be fruitful, and multiply, and replenish the earth, and subdue it: and have dominion over the fish of the sea, and over the fowl of the air, and over every living thing that moveth upon the earth.

And*p God said, Behold, I have given you every herb bearing seed, which is upon the face of all the earth, and every tree, in the which is the fruit of a tree yielding seed; to you it shall be for meat.
And*p to every beast of the earth, and to every fowl of the air, and to every thing that creepeth upon the earth, wherein there is life, I have given every green herb for meat: and it was so.
And*p God saw every thing that he had made, and, behold, it was very good. And the evening and the morning were the sixth day.
Genesis 2
Thus*p the heavens and the earth were finished, and all the host of them.
And*p on the seventh day God ended his work which he had made; and he rested on the seventh day from all his work which he had made.
And*p God blessed the seventh day, and sanctified it: because that in it he had rested from all his work which God created and made.
These*p are the generations of the heavens and of the earth when they were created, in the day that the Lord*s God made the earth and the heavens,

And*p every plant of the field before it was in the earth, and every herb of the field before it grew: for the Lord*s God had not caused it to rain upon the earth, and there was not a man to till the ground.
But*p there went up a mist from the earth, and watered the whole face of the ground.
And*p the Lord*s God formed man of the dust of the ground, and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life; and man became a living soul.
And*p the Lord*s God planted a garden eastward in Eden; and there he put the man whom he had formed.

And*p out of the ground made the Lord*s God to grow every tree that is pleasant to the sight, and good for food; the tree of life also in the midst of the garden, and the tree of knowledge of good and evil.
And*p a river went out of Eden to water the garden; and from thence it was parted, and became into four heads.
The*p name of the first is Pison: that is it which compasseth the whole land of Havilah, where there is gold;
And*p the gold of that land is good: there is bdellium and the onyx stone.
And*p the name of the second river is Gihon: the same is it that compasseth the whole land of Ethiopia.
And*p the name of the third river is Hiddekel: that is it which goeth toward the east of Assyria. And the fourth river is Euphrates.
And*p the Lord*s God took the man, and put him into the garden of Eden to dress it and to keep it.
And*p the Lord*s God commanded the man, saying, Of every tree of the garden thou mayest freely eat:
But*p of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, thou shalt not eat of it: for in the day that thou eatest thereof thou shalt surely die.
And*p the Lord*s God said, It is not good that the man should be alone; I will make him an help meet for him.

And*p out of the ground the Lord*s God formed every beast of the field, and every fowl of the air; and brought them unto Adam to see what he would call them: and whatsoever Adam called every living creature, that was the name thereof.
And*p Adam gave names to all cattle, and to the fowl of the air, and to every beast of the field; but for Adam there was not found an help meet for him.
And*p the Lord*s God caused a deep sleep to fall upon Adam, and he slept: and he took one of his ribs, and closed up the flesh instead thereof;
And*p the rib, which the Lord*s God had taken from man, made he a woman, and brought her unto the man.
And*p Adam said, This is now bone of my bones, and flesh of my flesh: she shall be called Woman, because she was taken out of Man.
Therefore*p shall a man leave his father and his mother, and shall cleave unto his wife: and they shall be one flesh.
And*p they were both naked, the man and his wife, and were not ashamed.
Genesis 3
Now*p the serpent was more subtil than any beast of the field which the Lord*s God had made. And he said unto the woman, Yea, hath God said, Ye shall not eat of every tree of the garden?
And*p the woman said unto the serpent, We may eat of the fruit of the trees of the garden:
But*p of the fruit of the tree which is in the midst of the garden, God hath said, Ye shall not eat of it, neither shall ye touch it, lest ye die.
And*p the serpent said unto the woman, Ye shall not surely die:
For*p God doth know that in the day ye eat thereof, then your eyes shall be opened, and ye shall be as gods, knowing good and evil.

And*p when the woman saw that the tree was good for food, and that it was pleasant to the eyes, and a tree to be desired to make one wise, she took of the fruit thereof, and did eat, and gave also unto her husband with her; and he did eat.
And*p the eyes of them both were opened, and they knew that they were naked; and they sewed fig leaves together, and made themselves aprons.
And*p they heard the voice of the Lord*s God walking in the garden in the cool of the day: and Adam and his wife hid themselves from the presence of the Lord*s God amongst the trees of the garden.
And*p the Lord*s God called unto Adam, and said unto him, Where art thou?
And*p he said, I heard thy voice in the garden, and I was afraid, because I was naked; and I hid myself.
And*p he said, Who told thee that thou wast naked? Hast thou eaten of the tree, whereof I commanded thee that thou shouldest not eat?
And*p the man said, The woman whom thou gavest to be with me, she gave me of the tree, and I did eat.
And*p the Lord*s God said unto the woman, What is this that thou hast done? And the woman said, The serpent beguiled me, and I did eat.

And*p the Lord*s God said unto the serpent, Because thou hast done this, thou art cursed above all cattle, and above every beast of the field; upon thy belly shalt thou go, and dust shalt thou eat all the days of thy life:
And*p I will put enmity between thee and the woman, and between thy seed and her seed; it shall bruise thy head, and thou shalt bruise his heel.
Unto*p the woman he said, I will greatly multiply thy sorrow and thy conception; in sorrow thou shalt bring forth children; and thy desire shall be to thy husband, and he shall rule over thee.

And*p unto Adam he said, Because thou hast hearkened unto the voice of thy wife, and hast eaten of the tree, of which I commanded thee, saying, Thou shalt not eat of it: cursed is the ground for thy sake; in sorrow shalt thou eat of it all the days of thy life;
Thorns*p also and thistles shall it bring forth to thee; and thou shalt eat the herb of the field;
In*p the sweat of thy face shalt thou eat bread, till thou return unto the ground; for out of it wast thou taken: for dust thou art, and unto dust shalt thou return.
And*p Adam called his wife's name Eve; because she was the mother of all living.
Unto*p Adam also and to his wife did the Lord*s God make coats of skins, and clothed them.
And*p the Lord*s God said, Behold, the man is become as one of us, to know good and evil: and now, lest he put forth his hand, and take also of the tree of life, and eat, and live for ever:
Therefore*p the Lord*s God sent him forth from the garden of Eden, to till the ground from whence he was taken.
So*p he drove out the man; and he placed at the east of the garden of Eden Cherubims, and a flaming sword which turned every way, to keep the way of the tree of life.
Genesis 4
And*p Adam knew Eve his wife; and she conceived, and bare Cain, and said, I have gotten a man from the Lord.*s
And*p she again bare his brother Abel. And Abel was a keeper of sheep, but Cain was a tiller of the ground.
And*p in process of time it came to pass, that Cain brought of the fruit of the ground an offering unto the Lord.*s
And*p Abel, he also brought of the firstlings of his flock and of the fat thereof. And the Lord*s had respect unto Abel and to his offering:
But*p unto Cain and to his offering he had not respect. And Cain was very wroth, and his countenance fell.
And*p the Lord*s said unto Cain, Why art thou wroth? and why is thy countenance fallen?
If*p thou doest well, shalt thou not be accepted? and if thou doest not well, sin lieth at the door. And unto thee shall be his desire, and thou shalt rule over him.
And*p Cain talked with Abel his brother: and it came to pass, when they were in the field, that Cain rose up against Abel his brother, and slew him.
And*p the Lord*s said unto Cain, Where is Abel thy brother? And he said, I know not: Am I my brother's keeper?
And*p he said, What hast thou done? the voice of thy brother's blood crieth unto me from the ground.
And*p now art thou cursed from the earth, which hath opened her mouth to receive thy brother's blood from thy hand;
When*p thou tillest the ground, it shall not henceforth yield unto thee her strength; a fugitive and a vagabond shalt thou be in the earth.
And*p Cain said unto the Lord,*s My punishment is greater than I can bear.

Behold,*p thou hast driven me out this day from the face of the earth; and from thy face shall I be hid; and I shall be a fugitive and a vagabond in the earth; and it shall come to pass, that every one that findeth me shall slay me.
And*p the Lord*s said unto him, Therefore whosoever slayeth Cain, vengeance shall be taken on him sevenfold. And the Lord*s set a mark upon Cain, lest any finding him should kill him.
And*p Cain went out from the presence of the Lord,*s and dwelt in the land of Nod, on the east of Eden.
And*p Cain knew his wife; and she conceived, and bare Enoch: and he builded a city, and called the name of the city, after the name of his son, Enoch.
And*p unto Enoch was born Irad: and Irad begat Mehujael: and Mehujael begat Methusael: and Methusael begat Lamech.
And*p Lamech took unto him two wives: the name of the one was Adah, and the name of the other Zillah.
And*p Adah bare Jabal: he was the father of such as dwell in tents, and of such as have cattle.
And*p his brother's name was Jubal: he was the father of all such as handle the harp and organ.
And*p Zillah, she also bare Tubal–cain, an instructor of every artificer in brass and iron: and the sister of Tubal–cain was Naamah.
And*p Lamech said unto his wives, Adah and Zillah, Hear my voice; ye wives of Lamech, hearken unto my speech: for I have slain a man to my wounding, and a young man to my hurt.
If*p Cain shall be avenged sevenfold, truly Lamech seventy and sevenfold.
And*p Adam knew his wife again; and she bare a son, and called his name Seth: For God, said she, hath appointed me another seed instead of Abel, whom Cain slew.
And*p to Seth, to him also there was born a son; and he called his name Enos: then began men to call upon the name of the Lord.*s
Genesis 5
This*p is the book of the generations of Adam. In the day that God created man, in the likeness of God made he him;
Male*p and female created he them; and blessed them, and called their name Adam, in the day when they were created.
And*p Adam lived an hundred and thirty years, and begat a son in his own likeness, after his image; and called his name Seth:
And*p the days of Adam after he had begotten Seth were eight hundred years: and he begat sons and daughters:
And*p all the days that Adam lived were nine hundred and thirty years: and he died.
And*p Seth lived an hundred and five years, and begat Enos:
And*p Seth lived after he begat Enos eight hundred and seven years, and begat sons and daughters:
And*p all the days of Seth were nine hundred and twelve years: and he died.
And*p Enos lived ninety years, and begat Cainan:
And*p Enos lived after he begat Cainan eight hundred and fifteen years, and begat sons and daughters:
And*p all the days of Enos were nine hundred and five years: and he died.
And*p Cainan lived seventy years, and begat Mahalaleel:
And*p Cainan lived after he begat Mahalaleel eight hundred and forty years, and begat sons and daughters:
And*p all the days of Cainan were nine hundred and ten years: and he died.
And*p Mahalaleel lived sixty and five years, and begat Jared:
And*p Mahalaleel lived after he begat Jared eight hundred and thirty years, and begat sons and daughters:
And*p all the days of Mahalaleel were eight hundred ninety and five years: and he died.
And*p Jared lived an hundred sixty and two years, and he begat Enoch:
And*p Jared lived after he begat Enoch eight hundred years, and begat sons and daughters:
And*p all the days of Jared were nine hundred sixty and two years: and he died.
And*p Enoch lived sixty and five years, and begat Methuselah:
And*p Enoch walked with God after he begat Methuselah three hundred years, and begat sons and daughters:
And*p all the days of Enoch were three hundred sixty and five years:
And*p Enoch walked with God: and he was not; for God took him.
And*p Methuselah lived an hundred eighty and seven years, and begat Lamech:
And*p Methuselah lived after he begat Lamech seven hundred eighty and two years, and begat sons and daughters:
And*p all the days of Methuselah were nine hundred sixty and nine years: and he died.
And*p Lamech lived an hundred eighty and two years, and begat a son:
And*p he called his name Noah, saying, This same shall comfort us concerning our work and toil of our hands, because of the ground which the Lord*s hath cursed.
And*p Lamech lived after he begat Noah five hundred ninety and five years, and begat sons and daughters:
And*p all the days of Lamech were seven hundred seventy and seven years: and he died.
And*p Noah was five hundred years old: and Noah begat Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
Genesis 6
And*p it came to pass, when men began to multiply on the face of the earth, and daughters were born unto them,
That*p the sons of God saw the daughters of men that they were fair; and they took them wives of all which they chose.
And*p the Lord*s said, My spirit shall not always strive with man, for that he also is flesh: yet his days shall be an hundred and twenty years.

There*p were giants in the earth in those days; and also after that, when the sons of God came in unto the daughters of men, and they bare children to them, the same became mighty men which were of old, men of renown.
And*p God*s saw that the wickedness of man was great in the earth, and that every imagination of the thoughts of his heart was only evil continually.
And*p it repented the Lord*s that he had made man on the earth, and it grieved him at his heart.

And*p the Lord*s said, I will destroy man whom I have created from the face of the earth; both man, and beast, and the creeping thing, and the fowls of the air; for it repenteth me that I have made them.
But*p Noah found grace in the eyes of the Lord.*s
These*p are the generations of Noah: Noah was a just man and perfect in his generations, and Noah walked with God.
And*p Noah begat three sons, Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
The*p earth also was corrupt before God, and the earth was filled with violence.
And*p God looked upon the earth, and, behold, it was corrupt; for all flesh had corrupted his way upon the earth.
And*p God said unto Noah, The end of all flesh is come before me; for the earth is filled with violence through them; and, behold, I will destroy them with the earth.
Make*p thee an ark of gopher wood; rooms shalt thou make in the ark, and shalt pitch it within and without with pitch.
And*p this is the fashion which thou shalt make it of: The length of the ark shall be three hundred cubits, the breadth of it fifty cubits, and the height of it thirty cubits.
A*p window shalt thou make to the ark, and in a cubit shalt thou finish it above; and the door of the ark shalt thou set in the side thereof; with lower, second, and third stories shalt thou make it.
And,*p behold, I, even I, do bring a flood of waters upon the earth, to destroy all flesh, wherein is the breath of life, from under heaven; and every thing that is in the earth shall die.
But*p with thee will I establish my covenant; and thou shalt come into the ark, thou, and thy sons, and thy wife, and thy sons' wives with thee.
And*p of every living thing of all flesh, two of every sort shalt thou bring into the ark, to keep them alive with thee; they shall be male and female.
Of*p fowls after their kind, and of cattle after their kind, of every creeping thing of the earth after his kind, two of every sort shall come unto thee, to keep them alive.
And*p take thou unto thee of all food that is eaten, and thou shalt gather it to thee; and it shall be for food for thee, and for them.
Thus*p did Noah; according to all that God commanded him, so did he.
Genesis 7
And*p the Lord*s said unto Noah, Come thou and all thy house into the ark; for thee have I seen righteous before me in this generation.
Of*p every clean beast thou shalt take to thee by sevens, the male and his female: and of beasts that are not clean by two, the male and his female.
Of*p fowls also of the air by sevens, the male and the female; to keep seed alive upon the face of all the earth.
For*p yet seven days, and I will cause it to rain upon the earth forty days and forty nights; and every living substance that I have made will I destroy from off the face of the earth.
And*p Noah did according unto all that the Lord*s commanded him.
And*p Noah was six hundred years old when the flood of waters was upon the earth.
And*p Noah went in, and his sons, and his wife, and his sons' wives with him, into the ark, because of the waters of the flood.
Of*p clean beasts, and of beasts that are not clean, and of fowls, and of every thing that creepeth upon the earth,
There*p went in two and two unto Noah into the ark, the male and the female, as God had commanded Noah.
And*p it came to pass after seven days, that the waters of the flood were upon the earth.

In*p the six hundredth year of Noah's life, in the second month, the seventeenth day of the month, the same day were all the fountains of the great deep broken up, and the windows of heaven were opened.
And*p the rain was upon the earth forty days and forty nights.
In*p the selfsame day entered Noah, and Shem, and Ham, and Japheth, the sons of Noah, and Noah's wife, and the three wives of his sons with them, into the ark;

They,*p and every beast after his kind, and all the cattle after their kind, and every creeping thing that creepeth upon the earth after his kind, and every fowl after his kind, every bird of every sort.
And*p they went in unto Noah into the ark, two and two of all flesh, wherein is the breath of life.
And*p they that went in, went in male and female of all flesh, as God had commanded him: and the Lord*s shut him in.
And*p the flood was forty days upon the earth; and the waters increased, and bare up the ark, and it was lift up above the earth.
And*p the waters prevailed, and were increased greatly upon the earth; and the ark went upon the face of the waters.
And*p the waters prevailed exceedingly upon the earth; and all the high hills, that were under the whole heaven, were covered.
Fifteen*p cubits upward did the waters prevail; and the mountains were covered.
And*p all flesh died that moved upon the earth, both of fowl, and of cattle, and of beast, and of every creeping thing that creepeth upon the earth, and every man:
All*p in whose nostrils was the breath of life, of all that was in the dry land, died.

And*p every living substance was destroyed which was upon the face of the ground, both man, and cattle, and the creeping things, and the fowl of the heaven; and they were destroyed from the earth: and Noah only remained alive, and they that were with him in the ark.
And*p the waters prevailed upon the earth an hundred and fifty days.
Genesis 8
And*p God remembered Noah, and every living thing, and all the cattle that was with him in the ark: and God made a wind to pass over the earth, and the waters assuaged;
The*p fountains also of the deep and the windows of heaven were stopped, and the rain from heaven was restrained;
And*p the waters returned from off the earth continually: and after the end of the hundred and fifty days the waters were abated.
And*p the ark rested in the seventh month, on the seventeenth day of the month, upon the mountains of Ararat.
And*p the waters decreased continually until the tenth month: in the tenth month, on the first day of the month, were the tops of the mountains seen.
And*p it came to pass at the end of forty days, that Noah opened the window of the ark which he had made:
And*p he sent forth a raven, which went forth to and fro, until the waters were dried up from off the earth.
Also*p he sent forth a dove from him, to see if the waters were abated from off the face of the ground;

But*p the dove found no rest for the sole of her foot, and she returned unto him into the ark, for the waters were on the face of the whole earth: then he put forth his hand, and took her, and pulled her in unto him into the ark.
And*p he stayed yet other seven days; and again he sent forth the dove out of the ark;
And*p the dove came in to him in the evening; and, lo, in her mouth was an olive leaf plucked off: so Noah knew that the waters were abated from off the earth.
And*p he stayed yet other seven days; and sent forth the dove; which returned not again unto him any more.

And*p it came to pass in the six hundredth and first year, in the first month, the first day of the month, the waters were dried up from off the earth: and Noah removed the covering of the ark, and looked, and, behold, the face of the ground was dry.
And*p in the second month, on the seven and twentieth day of the month, was the earth dried.
And*p God spake unto Noah, saying,
Go*p forth of the ark, thou, and thy wife, and thy sons, and thy sons' wives with thee.

Bring*p forth with thee every living thing that is with thee, of all flesh, both of fowl, and of cattle, and of every creeping thing that creepeth upon the earth; that they may breed abundantly in the earth, and be fruitful, and multiply upon the earth.
And*p Noah went forth, and his sons, and his wife, and his sons' wives with him:
Every*p beast, every creeping thing, and every fowl, and whatsoever creepeth upon the earth, after their kinds, went forth out of the ark.
And*p Noah builded an altar unto the Lord;*s and took of every clean beast, and of every clean fowl, and offered burnt offerings on the altar.

And*p the Lord*s smelled a sweet savour; and the Lord*s said in his heart, I will not again curse the ground any more for man's sake; for the imagination of man's heart is evil from his youth; neither will I again smite any more every thing living, as I have done.
While*p the earth remaineth, seedtime and harvest, and cold and heat, and summer and winter, and day and night shall not cease.
Genesis 9
And*p God blessed Noah and his sons, and said unto them, Be fruitful, and multiply, and replenish the earth.

And*p the fear of you and the dread of you shall be upon every beast of the earth, and upon every fowl of the air, upon all that moveth upon the earth, and upon all the fishes of the sea; into your hand are they delivered.
Every*p moving thing that liveth shall be meat for you; even as the green herb have I given you all things.
But*p flesh with the life thereof, which is the blood thereof, shall ye not eat.
And*p surely your blood of your lives will I require; at the hand of every beast will I require it, and at the hand of man; at the hand of every man's brother will I require the life of man.
Whoso*p sheddeth man's blood, by man shall his blood be shed: for in the image of God made he man.
And*p you, be ye fruitful, and multiply; bring forth abundantly in the earth, and multiply therein.
And*p God spake unto Noah, and to his sons with him, saying,
And*p I, behold, I establish my covenant with you, and with your seed after you;
And*p with every living creature that is with you, of the fowl, of the cattle, and of every beast of the earth with you; from all that go out of the ark, to every beast of the earth.
And*p I will establish my covenant with you; neither shall all flesh be cut off any more by the waters of a flood; neither shall there any more be a flood to destroy the earth.
And*p God said, This is the token of the covenant which I make between me and you and every living creature that is with you, for perpetual generations:
I*p do set my bow in the cloud, and it shall be for a token of a covenant between me and the earth.
And*p it shall come to pass, when I bring a cloud over the earth, that the bow shall be seen in the cloud:
And*p I will remember my covenant, which is between me and you and every living creature of all flesh; and the waters shall no more become a flood to destroy all flesh.
And*p the bow shall be in the cloud; and I will look upon it, that I may remember the everlasting covenant between God and every living creature of all flesh that is upon the earth.
And*p God said unto Noah, This is the token of the covenant, which I have established between me and all flesh that is upon the earth.
And*p the sons of Noah, that went forth of the ark, were Shem, and Ham, and Japheth: and Ham is the father of Canaan.
These*p are the three sons of Noah: and of them was the whole earth overspread.
And*p Noah began to be an husbandman, and he planted a vineyard:
And*p he drank of the wine, and was drunken; and he was uncovered within his tent.
And*p Ham, the father of Canaan, saw the nakedness of his father, and told his two brethren without.

And*p Shem and Japheth took a garment, and laid it upon both their shoulders, and went backward, and covered the nakedness of their father; and their faces were backward, and they saw not their father's nakedness.
And*p Noah awoke from his wine, and knew what his younger son had done unto him.
And*p he said, Cursed be Canaan; a servant of servants shall he be unto his brethren.
And*p he said, Blessed be the Lord*s God of Shem; and Canaan shall be his servant.
God*p shall enlarge Japheth, and he shall dwell in the tents of Shem; and Canaan shall be his servant.
And*p Noah lived after the flood three hundred and fifty years.
And*p all the days of Noah were nine hundred and fifty years: and he died.
Genesis 10
Now*p these are the generations of the sons of Noah, Shem, Ham, and Japheth: and unto them were sons born after the flood.
The*p sons of Japheth; Gomer, and Magog, and Madai, and Javan, and Tubal, and Meshech, and Tiras.
And*p the sons of Gomer; Ashkenaz, and Riphath, and Togarmah.
And*p the sons of Javan; Elishah, and Tarshish, Kittim, and Dodanim.
By*p these were the isles of the Gentiles divided in their lands; every one after his tongue, after their families, in their nations.
And*p the sons of Ham; Cush, and Mizraim, and Put, and Canaan.
And*p the sons of Cush; Seba, and Havilah, and Sabtah, and Raamah, and Sabtecha: and the sons of Raamah; Sheba, and Dedan.
And*p Cush begat Nimrod: he began to be a mighty one in the earth.
He*p was a mighty hunter before the Lord:*s wherefore it is said, Even as Nimrod the mighty hunter before the Lord.*s
And*p the beginning of his kingdom was Babel, and Erech, and Accad, and Calneh, in the land of Shinar.
Out*p of that land went forth Asshur, and builded Nineveh, and the city Rehoboth, and Calah,
And*p Resen between Nineveh and Calah: the same is a great city.
And*p Mizraim begat Ludim, and Anamim, and Lehabim, and Naphtuhim,
And*p Pathrusim, and Casluhim, (out of whom came the Philistines,) and Caphtorim.
And*p Canaan begat Sidon his firstborn, and Heth,
And*p the Jebusite, and the Amorite, and the Girgashite,
And*p the Hivite, and the Arkite, and the Sinite,
And*p the Arvadite, and the Zemarite, and the Hamathite: and afterward were the families of the Canaanites spread abroad.
And*p the border of the Canaanites was from Sidon, as thou comest to Gerar, unto Gaza; as thou goest, unto Sodom, and Gomorrah, and Admah, and Zeboiim, even unto Lasha.
These*p are the sons of Ham, after their families, after their tongues, in their countries, and in their nations.
Unto*p Shem also, the father of all the children of Eber, the brother of Japheth the elder, even to him were children born.
The*p children of Shem; Elam, and Asshur, and Arphaxad, and Lud, and Aram.
And*p the children of Aram; Uz, and Hul, and Gether, and Mash.
And*p Arphaxad begat Salah; and Salah begat Eber.
And*p unto Eber were born two sons: the name of one was Peleg; for in his days was the earth divided; and his brother's name was Joktan.
And*p Joktan begat Almodad, and Sheleph, and Hazarmaveth, and Jerah,
And*p Hadoram, and Uzal, and Diklah,
And*p Obal, and Abimael, and Sheba,
And*p Ophir, and Havilah, and Jobab: all these were the sons of Joktan.
And*p their dwelling was from Mesha, as thou goest unto Sephar a mount of the east.
These*p are the sons of Shem, after their families, after their tongues, in their lands, after their nations.
These*p are the families of the sons of Noah, after their generations, in their nations: and by these were the nations divided in the earth after the flood.
Genesis 11
And*p the whole earth was of one language, and of one speech.
And*p it came to pass, as they journeyed from the east, that they found a plain in the land of Shinar; and they dwelt there.
And*p they said one to another, Go to, let us make brick, and burn them thoroughly. And they had brick for stone, and slime had they for mortar.
And*p they said, Go to, let us build us a city and a tower, whose top may reach unto heaven; and let us make us a name, lest we be scattered abroad upon the face of the whole earth.
And*p the Lord*s came down to see the city and the tower, which the children of men builded.
And*p the Lord*s said, Behold, the people is one, and they have all one language; and this they begin to do: and now nothing will be restrained from them, which they have imagined to do.
Go*p to, let us go down, and there confound their language, that they may not understand one another's speech.
So*p the Lord*s scattered them abroad from thence upon the face of all the earth: and they left off to build the city.
Therefore*p is the name of it called Babel; because the Lord*s did there confound the language of all the earth: and from thence did the Lord*s scatter them abroad upon the face of all the earth.
These*p are the generations of Shem: Shem was an hundred years old, and begat Arphaxad two years after the flood:
And*p Shem lived after he begat Arphaxad five hundred years, and begat sons and daughters.
And*p Arphaxad lived five and thirty years, and begat Salah:
And*p Arphaxad lived after he begat Salah four hundred and three years, and begat sons and daughters.
And*p Salah lived thirty years, and begat Eber:
And*p Salah lived after he begat Eber four hundred and three years, and begat sons and daughters.
And*p Eber lived four and thirty years, and begat Peleg:
And*p Eber lived after he begat Peleg four hundred and thirty years, and begat sons and daughters.
And*p Peleg lived thirty years, and begat Reu:
And*p Peleg lived after he begat Reu two hundred and nine years, and begat sons and daughters.
And*p Reu lived two and thirty years, and begat Serug:
And*p Reu lived after he begat Serug two hundred and seven years, and begat sons and daughters.
And*p Serug lived thirty years, and begat Nahor:
And*p Serug lived after he begat Nahor two hundred years, and begat sons and daughters.
And*p Nahor lived nine and twenty years, and begat Terah:
And*p Nahor lived after he begat Terah an hundred and nineteen years, and begat sons and daughters.
And*p Terah lived seventy years, and begat Abram, Nahor, and Haran.
Now*p these are the generations of Terah: Terah begat Abram, Nahor, and Haran; and Haran begat Lot.
And*p Haran died before his father Terah in the land of his nativity, in Ur of the Chaldeans.
And*p Abram and Nahor took them wives: the name of Abram's wife was Sarai; and the name of Nahor's wife, Milcah, the daughter of Haran, the father of Milcah, and the father of Iscah.
But*p Sarai was barren; she had no child.

And*p Terah took Abram his son, and Lot the son of Haran his son's son, and Sarai his daughter in law, his son Abram's wife; and they went forth with them from Ur of the Chaldeans, to go into the land of Canaan; and they came unto Haran, and dwelt there.
And*p the days of Terah were two hundred and five years: and Terah died in Haran.
Genesis 12
Now*p the Lord*s had said unto Abram, Get thee out of thy country, and from thy kindred, and from thy father's house, unto a land that I will shew thee:
And*p I will make of thee a great nation, and I will bless thee, and make thy name great; and thou shalt be a blessing:
And*p I will bless them that bless thee, and curse him that curseth thee: and in thee shall all families of the earth be blessed.
So*p Abram departed, as the Lord*s had spoken unto him; and Lot went with him: and Abram was seventy and five years old when he departed out of Haran.

And*p Abram took Sarai his wife, and Lot his brother's son, and all their substance that they had gathered, and the souls that they had gotten in Haran; and they went forth to go into the land of Canaan; and into the land of Canaan they came.
And*p Abram passed through the land unto the place of Shechem, unto the plain of Moreh. And the Canaanite was then in the land.
And*p the Lord*s appeared unto Abram, and said, Unto thy seed will I give this land: and there builded he an altar unto the Lord,*s who appeared unto him.

And*p he removed from thence unto a mountain on the east of Beth–el, and pitched his tent, having Beth–el on the west, and Ai on the east: and there he builded an altar unto the Lord,*s and called upon the name of the Lord.*s
And*p Abram journeyed, going on still toward the south.
And*p there was a famine in the land: and Abram went down into Egypt to sojourn there; for the famine was grievous in the land.
And*p it came to pass, when he was come near to enter into Egypt, that he said unto Sarai his wife, Behold now, I know that thou art a fair woman to look upon:
Therefore*p it shall come to pass, when the Egyptians shall see thee, that they shall say, This is his wife: and they will kill me, but they will save thee alive.
Say,*p I pray thee, thou art my sister: that it may be well with me for thy sake; and my soul shall live because of thee.
And*p it came to pass, that, when Abram was come into Egypt, the Egyptians beheld the woman that she was very fair.
The*p princes also of Pharaoh saw her, and commended her before Pharaoh: and the woman was taken into Pharaoh's house.
And*p he entreated Abram well for her sake: and he had sheep, and oxen, and he asses, and menservants, and maidservants, and she asses, and camels.
And*p the Lord*s plagued Pharaoh and his house with great plagues because of Sarai Abram's wife.
And*p Pharaoh called Abram, and said, What is this that thou hast done unto me? why didst thou not tell me that she was thy wife?
Why*p saidst thou, She is my sister? so I might have taken her to me to wife: now therefore behold thy wife, take her, and go thy way.
And*p Pharaoh commanded his men concerning him: and they sent him away, and his wife, and all that he had.
Genesis 13
And*p Abram went up out of Egypt, he, and his wife, and all that he had, and Lot with him, into the south.
And*p Abram was very rich in cattle, in silver, and in gold.
And*p he went on his journeys from the south even to Beth–el, unto the place where his tent had been at the beginning, between Beth–el and Ai;
Unto*p the place of the altar, which he had made there at the first: and there Abram called on the name of the Lord.*s
And*p Lot also, which went with Abram, had flocks, and herds, and tents.
And*p the land was not able to bear them, that they might dwell together: for their substance was great, so that they could not dwell together.
And*p there was a strife between the herdmen of Abram's cattle and the herdmen of Lot's cattle: and the Canaanite and the Perizzite dwelled then in the land.
And*p Abram said unto Lot, Let there be no strife, I pray thee, between me and thee, and between my herdmen and thy herdmen; for we be brethren.

Is*p not the whole land before thee? separate thyself, I pray thee, from me: if thou wilt take the left hand, then I will go to the right; or if thou depart to the right hand, then I will go to the left.

And*p Lot lifted up his eyes, and beheld all the plain of Jordan, that it was well watered every where, before the Lord*s destroyed Sodom and Gomorrah, even as the garden of the Lord,*s like the land of Egypt, as thou comest unto Zoar.
Then*p Lot chose him all the plain of Jordan; and Lot journeyed east: and they separated themselves the one from the other.
Abram*p dwelled in the land of Canaan, and Lot dwelled in the cities of the plain, and pitched his tent toward Sodom.
But*p the men of Sodom were wicked and sinners before the Lord*s exceedingly.
And*p the Lord*s said unto Abram, after that Lot was separated from him, Lift up now thine eyes, and look from the place where thou art northward, and southward, and eastward, and westward:
For*p all the land which thou seest, to thee will I give it, and to thy seed for ever.
And*p I will make thy seed as the dust of the earth: so that if a man can number the dust of the earth, then shall thy seed also be numbered.
Arise,*p walk through the land in the length of it and in the breadth of it; for I will give it unto thee.
Then*p Abram removed his tent, and came and dwelt in the plain of Mamre, which is in Hebron, and built there an altar unto the Lord.*s
Genesis 14
And*p it came to pass in the days of Amraphel king of Shinar, Arioch king of Ellasar, Chedorlaomer king of Elam, and Tidal king of nations;
That*p these made war with Bera king of Sodom, and with Birsha king of Gomorrah, Shinab king of Admah, and Shemeber king of Zeboiim, and the king of Bela, which is Zoar.
All*p these were joined together in the vale of Siddim, which is the salt sea.
Twelve*p years they served Chedorlaomer, and in the thirteenth year they rebelled.
And*p in the fourteenth year came Chedorlaomer, and the kings that were with him, and smote the Rephaims in Ashteroth Karnaim, and the Zuzims in Ham, and the Emims in Shaveh Kiriathaim,
And*p the Horites in their mount Seir, unto El–paran, which is by the wilderness.
And*p they returned, and came to En–mishpat, which is Kadesh, and smote all the country of the Amalekites, and also the Amorites, that dwelt in Hazazon–tamar.

And*p there went out the king of Sodom, and the king of Gomorrah, and the king of Admah, and the king of Zeboiim, and the king of Bela (the same is Zoar;) and they joined battle with them in the vale of Siddim;
With*p Chedorlaomer the king of Elam, and with Tidal king of nations, and Amraphel king of Shinar, and Arioch king of Ellasar; four kings with five.
And*p the vale of Siddim was full of slimepits; and the kings of Sodom and Gomorrah fled, and fell there; and they that remained fled to the mountain.
And*p they took all the goods of Sodom and Gomorrah, and all their victuals, and went their way.
And*p they took Lot, Abram's brother's son, who dwelt in Sodom, and his goods, and departed.
And*p there came one that had escaped, and told Abram the Hebrew; for he dwelt in the plain of Mamre the Amorite, brother of Eshcol, and brother of Aner: and these were confederate with Abram.
And*p when Abram heard that his brother was taken captive, he armed his trained servants, born in his own house, three hundred and eighteen, and pursued them unto Dan.
And*p he divided himself against them, he and his servants, by night, and smote them, and pursued them unto Hobah, which is on the left hand of Damascus.
And*p he brought back all the goods, and also brought again his brother Lot, and his goods, and the women also, and the people.
And*p the king of Sodom went out to meet him after his return from the slaughter of Chedorlaomer, and of the kings that were with him, at the valley of Shaveh, which is the king's dale.
And*p Melchizedek king of Salem brought forth bread and wine: and he was the priest of the most high God.
And*p he blessed him, and said, Blessed be Abram of the most high God, possessor of heaven and earth:
And*p blessed be the most high God, which hath delivered thine enemies into thy hand. And he gave him tithes of all.
And*p the king of Sodom said unto Abram, Give me the persons, and take the goods to thyself.
And*p Abram said to the king of Sodom, I have lift up mine hand unto the Lord,*s the most high God, the possessor of heaven and earth,
That*p I will not take from a thread even to a shoelatchet, and that I will not take any thing that is thine, lest thou shouldest say, I have made Abram rich:
Save*p only that which the young men have eaten, and the portion of the men which went with me, Aner, Eshcol, and Mamre; let them take their portion.
Genesis 15
After*p these things the word of the Lord*s came unto Abram in a vision, saying, Fear not, Abram: I am thy shield, and thy exceeding great reward.
And*p Abram said, Lord God,*s what wilt thou give me, seeing I go childless, and the steward of my house is this Eliezer of Damascus?
And*p Abram said, Behold, to me thou hast given no seed: and, lo, one born in my house is mine heir.
And,*p behold, the word of the Lord*s came unto him, saying, This shall not be thine heir; but he that shall come forth out of thine own bowels shall be thine heir.
And*p he brought him forth abroad, and said, Look now toward heaven, and tell the stars, if thou be able to number them: and he said unto him, So shall thy seed be.
And*p he believed in the Lord;*s and he counted it to him for righteousness.
And*p he said unto him, I am the Lord*s that brought thee out of Ur of the Chaldeans, to give thee this land to inherit it.
And*p he said, Lord God,*s whereby shall I know that I shall inherit it?
And*p he said unto him, Take me an heifer of three years old, and a she goat of three years old, and a ram of three years old, and a turtledove, and a young pigeon.
And*p he took unto him all these, and divided them in the midst, and laid each piece one against another: but the birds divided he not.
And*p when the fowls came down upon the carcases, Abram drove them away.
And*p when the sun was going down, a deep sleep fell upon Abram; and, lo, an horror of great darkness fell upon him.
And*p he said unto Abram, Know of a surety that thy seed shall be a stranger in a land that is not theirs, and shall serve them; and they shall afflict them four hundred years;
And*p also that nation, whom they shall serve, will I judge: and afterward shall they come out with great substance.
And*p thou shalt go to thy fathers in peace; thou shalt be buried in a good old age.
But*p in the fourth generation they shall come hither again: for the iniquity of the Amorites is not yet full.
And*p it came to pass, that, when the sun went down, and it was dark, behold a smoking furnace, and a burning lamp that passed between those pieces.
In*p the same day the Lord*s made a covenant with Abram, saying, Unto thy seed have I given this land, from the river of Egypt unto the great river, the river Euphrates:
The*p Kenites, and the Kenizzites, and the Kadmonites,
And*p the Hittites, and the Perizzites, and the Rephaims,
And*p the Amorites, and the Canaanites, and the Girgashites, and the Jebusites.
Genesis 16
Now*p Sarai Abram's wife bare him no children: and she had an handmaid, an Egyptian, whose name was Hagar.

And*p Sarai said unto Abram, Behold now, the Lord*s hath restrained me from bearing: I pray thee, go in unto my maid; it may be that I may obtain children by her. And Abram hearkened to the voice of Sarai.
And*p Sarai Abram's wife took Hagar her maid the Egyptian, after Abram had dwelt ten years in the land of Canaan, and gave her to her husband Abram to be his wife.
And*p he went in unto Hagar, and she conceived: and when she saw that she had conceived, her mistress was despised in her eyes.
And*p Sarai said unto Abram, My wrong be upon thee: I have given my maid into thy bosom; and when she saw that she had conceived, I was despised in her eyes: the Lord*s judge between me and thee.
But*p Abram said unto Sarai, Behold, thy maid is in thy hand; do to her as it pleaseth thee. And when Sarai dealt hardly with her, she fled from her face.
And*p the angel of the Lord*s found her by a fountain of water in the wilderness, by the fountain in the way to Shur.
And*p he said, Hagar, Sarai's maid, whence camest thou? and whither wilt thou go? And she said, I flee from the face of my mistress Sarai.
And*p the angel of the Lord*s said unto her, Return to thy mistress, and submit thyself under her hands.
And*p the angel of the Lord*s said unto her, I will multiply thy seed exceedingly, that it shall not be numbered for multitude.
And*p the angel of the Lord*s said unto her, Behold, thou art with child, and shalt bear a son, and shalt call his name Ishmael; because the Lord*s hath heard thy affliction.
And*p he will be a wild man; his hand will be against every man, and every man's hand against him; and he shall dwell in the presence of all his brethren.
And*p she called the name of the Lord*s that spake unto her, Thou God seest me: for she said, Have I also here looked after him that seeth me?
Wherefore*p the well was called Beer–lahai–roi; behold, it is between Kadesh and Bered.
And*p Hagar bare Abram a son: and Abram called his son's name, which Hagar bare, Ishmael.
And*p Abram was fourscore and six years old, when Hagar bare Ishmael to Abram.
Genesis 17
And*p when Abram was ninety years old and nine, the Lord*s appeared to Abram, and said unto him, I am the Almighty God; walk before me, and be thou perfect.
And*p I will make my covenant between me and thee, and will multiply thee exceedingly.
And*p Abram fell on his face: and God talked with him, saying,
As*p for me, behold, my covenant is with thee, and thou shalt be a father of many nations.
Neither*p shall thy name any more be called Abram, but thy name shall be Abraham; for a father of many nations have I made thee.
And*p I will make thee exceeding fruitful, and I will make nations of thee, and kings shall come out of thee.
And*p I will establish my covenant between me and thee and thy seed after thee in their generations for an everlasting covenant, to be a God unto thee, and to thy seed after thee.
And*p I will give unto thee, and to thy seed after thee, the land wherein thou art a stranger, all the land of Canaan, for an everlasting possession; and I will be their God.
And*p God said unto Abraham, Thou shalt keep my covenant therefore, thou, and thy seed after thee in their generations.
This*p is my covenant, which ye shall keep, between me and you and thy seed after thee; Every man child among you shall be circumcised.
And*p ye shall circumcise the flesh of your foreskin; and it shall be a token of the covenant betwixt me and you.
And*p he that is eight days old shall be circumcised among you, every man child in your generations, he that is born in the house, or bought with money of any stranger, which is not of thy seed.
He*p that is born in thy house, and he that is bought with thy money, must needs be circumcised: and my covenant shall be in your flesh for an everlasting covenant.
And*p the uncircumcised man child whose flesh of his foreskin is not circumcised, that soul shall be cut off from his people; he hath broken my covenant.
And*p God said unto Abraham, As for Sarai thy wife, thou shalt not call her name Sarai, but Sarah shall her name be.
And*p I will bless her, and give thee a son also of her: yea, I will bless her, and she shall be a mother of nations; kings of people shall be of her.
Then*p Abraham fell upon his face, and laughed, and said in his heart, Shall a child be born unto him that is an hundred years old? and shall Sarah, that is ninety years old, bear?
And*p Abraham said unto God, O that Ishmael might live before thee!
And*p God said, Sarah thy wife shall bear thee a son indeed; and thou shalt call his name Isaac: and I will establish my covenant with him for an everlasting covenant, and with his seed after him.
And*p as for Ishmael, I have heard thee: Behold, I have blessed him, and will make him fruitful, and will multiply him exceedingly; twelve princes shall he beget, and I will make him a great nation.
But*p my covenant will I establish with Isaac, which Sarah shall bear unto thee at this set time in the next year.
And*p he left off talking with him, and God went up from Abraham.

And*p Abraham took Ishmael his son, and all that were born in his house, and all that were bought with his money, every male among the men of Abraham's house; and circumcised the flesh of their foreskin in the selfsame day, as God had said unto him.
And*p Abraham was ninety years old and nine, when he was circumcised in the flesh of his foreskin.
And*p Ishmael his son was thirteen years old, when he was circumcised in the flesh of his foreskin.
In*p the selfsame day was Abraham circumcised, and Ishmael his son.
And*p all the men of his house, born in the house, and bought with money of the stranger, were circumcised with him.
Genesis 18
And*p the Lord*s appeared unto him in the plains of Mamre: and he sat in the tent door in the heat of the day;
And*p he lift up his eyes and looked, and, lo, three men stood by him: and when he saw them, he ran to meet them from the tent door, and bowed himself toward the ground,
And*p said, My Lord, if now I have found favour in thy sight, pass not away, I pray thee, from thy servant:
Let*p a little water, I pray you, be fetched, and wash your feet, and rest yourselves under the tree:
And*p I will fetch a morsel of bread, and comfort ye your hearts; after that ye shall pass on: for therefore are ye come to your servant. And they said, So do, as thou hast said.
And*p Abraham hastened into the tent unto Sarah, and said, Make ready quickly three measures of fine meal, knead it, and make cakes upon the hearth.
And*p Abraham ran unto the herd, and fetched a calf tender and good, and gave it unto a young man; and he hasted to dress it.
And*p he took butter, and milk, and the calf which he had dressed, and set it before them; and he stood by them under the tree, and they did eat.
And*p they said unto him, Where is Sarah thy wife? And he said, Behold, in the tent.
And*p he said, I will certainly return unto thee according to the time of life; and, lo, Sarah thy wife shall have a son. And Sarah heard it in the tent door, which was behind him.
Now*p Abraham and Sarah were old and well stricken in age; and it ceased to be with Sarah after the manner of women.
Therefore*p Sarah laughed within herself, saying, After I am waxed old shall I have pleasure, my lord being old also?
And*p the Lord*s said unto Abraham, Wherefore did Sarah laugh, saying, Shall I of a surety bear a child, which am old?
Is*p any thing too hard for the Lord?*s At the time appointed I will return unto thee, according to the time of life, and Sarah shall have a son.
Then*p Sarah denied, saying, I laughed not; for she was afraid. And he said, Nay; but thou didst laugh.
And*p the men rose up from thence, and looked toward Sodom: and Abraham went with them to bring them on the way.
And*p the Lord*s said, Shall I hide from Abraham that thing which I do;
Seeing*p that Abraham shall surely become a great and mighty nation, and all the nations of the earth shall be blessed in him?

For*p I know him, that he will command his children and his household after him, and they shall keep the way of the Lord,*s to do justice and judgment; that the Lord*s may bring upon Abraham that which he hath spoken of him.
And*p the Lord*s said, Because the cry of Sodom and Gomorrah is great, and because their sin is very grievous;
I*p will go down now, and see whether they have done altogether according to the cry of it, which is come unto me; and if not, I will know.
And*p the men turned their faces from thence, and went toward Sodom: but Abraham stood yet before the Lord.*s
And*p Abraham drew near, and said, Wilt thou also destroy the righteous with the wicked?
Peradventure*p there be fifty righteous within the city: wilt thou also destroy and not spare the place for the fifty righteous that are therein?

That*p be far from thee to do after this manner, to slay the righteous with the wicked: and that the righteous should be as the wicked, that be far from thee: Shall not the Judge of all the earth do right?
And*p the Lord*s said, If I find in Sodom fifty righteous within the city, then I will spare all the place for their sakes.
And*p Abraham answered and said, Behold now, I have taken upon me to speak unto the Lord, which am but dust and ashes:
Peradventure*p there shall lack five of the fifty righteous: wilt thou destroy all the city for lack of five? And he said, If I find there forty and five, I will not destroy it.
And*p he spake unto him yet again, and said, Peradventure there shall be forty found there. And he said, I will not do it for forty's sake.
And*p he said unto him, Oh let not the Lord be angry, and I will speak: Peradventure there shall thirty be found there. And he said, I will not do it, if I find thirty there.
And*p he said, Behold now, I have taken upon me to speak unto the Lord: Peradventure there shall be twenty found there. And he said, I will not destroy it for twenty's sake.
And*p he said, Oh let not the Lord be angry, and I will speak yet but this once: Peradventure ten shall be found there. And he said, I will not destroy it for ten's sake.
And*p the Lord*s went his way, as soon as he had left communing with Abraham: and Abraham returned unto his place.
Genesis 19
And*p there came two angels to Sodom at even; and Lot sat in the gate of Sodom: and Lot seeing them rose up to meet them; and he bowed himself with his face toward the ground;

And*p he said, Behold now, my lords, turn in, I pray you, into your servant's house, and tarry all night, and wash your feet, and ye shall rise up early, and go on your ways. And they said, Nay; but we will abide in the street all night.
And*p he pressed upon them greatly; and they turned in unto him, and entered into his house; and he made them a feast, and did bake unleavened bread, and they did eat.
But*p before they lay down, the men of the city, even the men of Sodom, compassed the house round, both old and young, all the people from every quarter:
And*p they called unto Lot, and said unto him, Where are the men which came in to thee this night? bring them out unto us, that we may know them.
And*p Lot went out at the door unto them, and shut the door after him,
And*p said, I pray you, brethren, do not so wickedly.

Behold*p now, I have two daughters which have not known man; let me, I pray you, bring them out unto you, and do ye to them as is good in your eyes: only unto these men do nothing; for therefore came they under the shadow of my roof.

And*p they said, Stand back. And they said again, This one fellow came in to sojourn, and he will needs be a judge: now will we deal worse with thee, than with them. And they pressed sore upon the man, even Lot, and came near to break the door.
But*p the men put forth their hand, and pulled Lot into the house to them, and shut to the door.
And*p they smote the men that were at the door of the house with blindness, both small and great: so that they wearied themselves to find the door.
And*p the men said unto Lot, Hast thou here any besides? son in law, and thy sons, and thy daughters, and whatsoever thou hast in the city, bring them out of this place:
For*p we will destroy this place, because the cry of them is waxen great before the face of the Lord;*s and the Lord*s hath sent us to destroy it.

And*p Lot went out, and spake unto his sons in law, which married his daughters, and said, Up, get you out of this place; for the Lord*s will destroy this city. But he seemed as one that mocked unto his sons in law.
And*p when the morning arose, then the angels hastened Lot, saying, Arise, take thy wife, and thy two daughters, which are here; lest thou be consumed in the iniquity of the city.

And*p while he lingered, the men laid hold upon his hand, and upon the hand of his wife, and upon the hand of his two daughters; the Lord*s being merciful unto him: and they brought him forth, and set him without the city.

And*p it came to pass, when they had brought them forth abroad, that he said, Escape for thy life; look not behind thee, neither stay thou in all the plain; escape to the mountain, lest thou be consumed.
And*p Lot said unto them, Oh, not so, my Lord:

Behold*p now, thy servant hath found grace in thy sight, and thou hast magnified thy mercy, which thou hast shewed unto me in saving my life; and I cannot escape to the mountain, lest some evil take me, and I die:
Behold*p now, this city is near to flee unto, and it is a little one: Oh, let me escape thither, (is it not a little one?) and my soul shall live.
And*p he said unto him, See, I have accepted thee concerning this thing also, that I will not overthrow this city, for the which thou hast spoken.
Haste*p thee, escape thither; for I cannot do any thing till thou be come thither. Therefore the name of the city was called Zoar.
The*p sun was risen upon the earth when Lot entered into Zoar.
Then*p the Lord*s rained upon Sodom and upon Gomorrah brimstone and fire from the Lord*s out of heaven;
And*p he overthrew those cities, and all the plain, and all the inhabitants of the cities, and that which grew upon the ground.
But*p his wife looked back from behind him, and she became a pillar of salt.
And*p Abraham gat up early in the morning to the place where he stood before the Lord:*s
And*p he looked toward Sodom and Gomorrah, and toward all the land of the plain, and beheld, and, lo, the smoke of the country went up as the smoke of a furnace.
And*p it came to pass, when God destroyed the cities of the plain, that God remembered Abraham, and sent Lot out of the midst of the overthrow, when he overthrew the cities in the which Lot dwelt.
And*p Lot went up out of Zoar, and dwelt in the mountain, and his two daughters with him; for he feared to dwell in Zoar: and he dwelt in a cave, he and his two daughters.
And*p the firstborn said unto the younger, Our father is old, and there is not a man in the earth to come in unto us after the manner of all the earth:
Come,*p let us make our father drink wine, and we will lie with him, that we may preserve seed of our father.
And*p they made their father drink wine that night: and the firstborn went in, and lay with her father; and he perceived not when she lay down, nor when she arose.

And*p it came to pass on the morrow, that the firstborn said unto the younger, Behold, I lay yesternight with my father: let us make him drink wine this night also; and go thou in, and lie with him, that we may preserve seed of our father.
And*p they made their father drink wine that night also: and the younger arose, and lay with him; and he perceived not when she lay down, nor when she arose.
Thus*p were both the daughters of Lot with child by their father.
And*p the firstborn bare a son, and called his name Moab: the same is the father of the Moabites unto this day.
And*p the younger, she also bare a son, and called his name Ben–ammi: the same is the father of the children of Ammon unto this day.
Genesis 20
And*p Abraham journeyed from thence toward the south country, and dwelled between Kadesh and Shur, and sojourned in Gerar.
And*p Abraham said of Sarah his wife, She is my sister: and Abimelech king of Gerar sent, and took Sarah.
But*p God came to Abimelech in a dream by night, and said to him, Behold, thou art but a dead man, for the woman which thou hast taken; for she is a man's wife.
But*p Abimelech had not come near her: and he said, Lord, wilt thou slay also a righteous nation?
Said*p he not unto me, She is my sister? and she, even she herself said, He is my brother: in the integrity of my heart and innocency of my hands have I done this.
And*p God said unto him in a dream, Yea, I know that thou didst this in the integrity of thy heart; for I also withheld thee from sinning against me: therefore suffered I thee not to touch her.

Now*p therefore restore the man his wife; for he is a prophet, and he shall pray for thee, and thou shalt live: and if thou restore her not, know thou that thou shalt surely die, thou, and all that are thine.
Therefore*p Abimelech rose early in the morning, and called all his servants, and told all these things in their ears: and the men were sore afraid.

Then*p Abimelech called Abraham, and said unto him, What hast thou done unto us? and what have I offended thee, that thou hast brought on me and on my kingdom a great sin? thou hast done deeds unto me that ought not to be done.
And*p Abimelech said unto Abraham, What sawest thou, that thou hast done this thing?
And*p Abraham said, Because I thought, Surely the fear of God is not in this place; and they will slay me for my wife's sake.
And*p yet indeed she is my sister; she is the daughter of my father, but not the daughter of my mother; and she became my wife.

And*p it came to pass, when God caused me to wander from my father's house, that I said unto her, This is thy kindness which thou shalt shew unto me; at every place whither we shall come, say of me, He is my brother.
And*p Abimelech took sheep, and oxen, and menservants, and womenservants, and gave them unto Abraham, and restored him Sarah his wife.
And*p Abimelech said, Behold, my land is before thee: dwell where it pleaseth thee.

And*p unto Sarah he said, Behold, I have given thy brother a thousand pieces of silver: behold, he is to thee a covering of the eyes, unto all that are with thee, and with all other: thus she was reproved.
So*p Abraham prayed unto God: and God healed Abimelech, and his wife, and his maidservants; and they bare children.
For*p the Lord*s had fast closed up all the wombs of the house of Abimelech, because of Sarah Abraham's wife.
Genesis 21
And*p the Lord*s visited Sarah as he had said, and the Lord*s did unto Sarah as he had spoken.
For*p Sarah conceived, and bare Abraham a son in his old age, at the set time of which God had spoken to him.
And*p Abraham called the name of his son that was born unto him, whom Sarah bare to him, Isaac.
And*p Abraham circumcised his son Isaac being eight days old, as God had commanded him.
And*p Abraham was an hundred years old, when his son Isaac was born unto him.
And*p Sarah said, God hath made me to laugh, so that all that hear will laugh with me.
And*p she said, Who would have said unto Abraham, that Sarah should have given children suck? for I have born him a son in his old age.
And*p the child grew, and was weaned: and Abraham made a great feast the same day that Isaac was weaned.
And*p Sarah saw the son of Hagar the Egyptian, which she had born unto Abraham, mocking.
Wherefore*p she said unto Abraham, Cast out this bondwoman and her son: for the son of this bondwoman shall not be heir with my son, even with Isaac.
And*p the thing was very grievous in Abraham's sight because of his son.

And*p God said unto Abraham, Let it not be grievous in thy sight because of the lad, and because of thy bondwoman; in all that Sarah hath said unto thee, hearken unto her voice; for in Isaac shall thy seed be called.
And*p also of the son of the bondwoman will I make a nation, because he is thy seed.

And*p Abraham rose up early in the morning, and took bread, and a bottle of water, and gave it unto Hagar, putting it on her shoulder, and the child, and sent her away: and she departed, and wandered in the wilderness of Beer–sheba.
And*p the water was spent in the bottle, and she cast the child under one of the shrubs.

And*p she went, and sat her down over against him a good way off, as it were a bowshot: for she said, Let me not see the death of the child. And she sat over against him, and lift up her voice, and wept.
And*p God heard the voice of the lad; and the angel of God called to Hagar out of heaven, and said unto her, What aileth thee, Hagar? fear not; for God hath heard the voice of the lad where he is.
Arise,*p lift up the lad, and hold him in thine hand; for I will make him a great nation.
And*p God opened her eyes, and she saw a well of water; and she went, and filled the bottle with water, and gave the lad drink.
And*p God was with the lad; and he grew, and dwelt in the wilderness, and became an archer.
And*p he dwelt in the wilderness of Paran: and his mother took him a wife out of the land of Egypt.
And*p it came to pass at that time, that Abimelech and Phichol the chief captain of his host spake unto Abraham, saying, God is with thee in all that thou doest:

Now*p therefore swear unto me here by God that thou wilt not deal falsely with me, nor with my son, nor with my son's son: but according to the kindness that I have done unto thee, thou shalt do unto me, and to the land wherein thou hast sojourned.
And*p Abraham said, I will swear.
And*p Abraham reproved Abimelech because of a well of water, which Abimelech's servants had violently taken away.
And*p Abimelech said, I wot not who hath done this thing: neither didst thou tell me, neither yet heard I of it, but to day.
And*p Abraham took sheep and oxen, and gave them unto Abimelech; and both of them made a covenant.
And*p Abraham set seven ewe lambs of the flock by themselves.
And*p Abimelech said unto Abraham, What mean these seven ewe lambs which thou hast set by themselves?
And*p he said, For these seven ewe lambs shalt thou take of my hand, that they may be a witness unto me, that I have digged this well.
Wherefore*p he called that place Beer–sheba; because there they sware both of them.
Thus*p they made a covenant at Beer–sheba: then Abimelech rose up, and Phichol the chief captain of his host, and they returned into the land of the Philistines.
And*p Abraham planted a grove in Beer–sheba, and called there on the name of the Lord,*s the everlasting God.
And*p Abraham sojourned in the Philistines' land many days.
Genesis 22
And*p it came to pass after these things, that God did tempt Abraham, and said unto him, Abraham: and he said, Behold, here I am.

And*p he said, Take now thy son, thine only son Isaac, whom thou lovest, and get thee into the land of Moriah; and offer him there for a burnt offering upon one of the mountains which I will tell thee of.

And*p Abraham rose up early in the morning, and saddled his ass, and took two of his young men with him, and Isaac his son, and clave the wood for the burnt offering, and rose up, and went unto the place of which God had told him.
Then*p on the third day Abraham lifted up his eyes, and saw the place afar off.
And*p Abraham said unto his young men, Abide ye here with the ass; and I and the lad will go yonder and worship, and come again to you.
And*p Abraham took the wood of the burnt offering, and laid it upon Isaac his son; and he took the fire in his hand, and a knife; and they went both of them together.
And*p Isaac spake unto Abraham his father, and said, My father: and he said, Here am I, my son. And he said, Behold the fire and the wood: but where is the lamb for a burnt offering?
And*p Abraham said, My son, God will provide himself a lamb for a burnt offering: so they went both of them together.
And*p they came to the place which God had told him of; and Abraham built an altar there, and laid the wood in order, and bound Isaac his son, and laid him on the altar upon the wood.
And*p Abraham stretched forth his hand, and took the knife to slay his son.
And*p the angel of the Lord*s called unto him out of heaven, and said, Abraham, Abraham: and he said, Here am I.
And*p he said, Lay not thine hand upon the lad, neither do thou any thing unto him: for now I know that thou fearest God, seeing thou hast not withheld thy son, thine only son from me.

And*p Abraham lifted up his eyes, and looked, and behold behind him a ram caught in a thicket by his horns: and Abraham went and took the ram, and offered him up for a burnt offering in the stead of his son.
And*p Abraham called the name of that place Jehovah–jireh: as it is said to this day, In the mount of the Lord*s it shall be seen.
And*p the angel of the Lord*s called unto Abraham out of heaven the second time,
And*p said, By myself have I sworn, saith the Lord,*s for because thou hast done this thing, and hast not withheld thy son, thine only son:

That*p in blessing I will bless thee, and in multiplying I will multiply thy seed as the stars of the heaven, and as the sand which is upon the sea shore; and thy seed shall possess the gate of his enemies;
And*p in thy seed shall all the nations of the earth be blessed; because thou hast obeyed my voice.
So*p Abraham returned unto his young men, and they rose up and went together to Beer–sheba; and Abraham dwelt at Beer–sheba.
And*p it came to pass after these things, that it was told Abraham, saying, Behold, Milcah, she hath also born children unto thy brother Nahor;
Huz*p his firstborn, and Buz his brother, and Kemuel the father of Aram,
And*p Chesed, and Hazo, and Pildash, and Jidlaph, and Bethuel.
And*p Bethuel begat Rebekah: these eight Milcah did bear to Nahor, Abraham's brother.
And*p his concubine, whose name was Reumah, she bare also Tebah, and Gaham, and Thahash, and Maachah.
Genesis 23
And*p Sarah was an hundred and seven and twenty years old: these were the years of the life of Sarah.
And*p Sarah died in Kirjath–arba; the same is Hebron in the land of Canaan: and Abraham came to mourn for Sarah, and to weep for her.
And*p Abraham stood up from before his dead, and spake unto the sons of Heth, saying,
I*p am a stranger and a sojourner with you: give me a possession of a buryingplace with you, that I may bury my dead out of my sight.
And*p the children of Heth answered Abraham, saying unto him,
Hear*p us, my lord: thou art a mighty prince among us: in the choice of our sepulchres bury thy dead; none of us shall withhold from thee his sepulchre, but that thou mayest bury thy dead.
And*p Abraham stood up, and bowed himself to the people of the land, even to the children of Heth.
And*p he communed with them, saying, If it be your mind that I should bury my dead out of my sight; hear me, and entreat for me to Ephron the son of Zohar,
That*p he may give me the cave of Machpelah, which he hath, which is in the end of his field; for as much money as it is worth he shall give it me for a possession of a buryingplace amongst you.
And*p Ephron dwelt among the children of Heth: and Ephron the Hittite answered Abraham in the audience of the children of Heth, even of all that went in at the gate of his city, saying,
Nay,*p my lord, hear me: the field give I thee, and the cave that is therein, I give it thee; in the presence of the sons of my people give I it thee: bury thy dead.
And*p Abraham bowed down himself before the people of the land.

And*p he spake unto Ephron in the audience of the people of the land, saying, But if thou wilt give it, I pray thee, hear me: I will give thee money for the field; take it of me, and I will bury my dead there.
And*p Ephron answered Abraham, saying unto him,
My*p lord, hearken unto me: the land is worth four hundred shekels of silver; what is that betwixt me and thee? bury therefore thy dead.
And*p Abraham hearkened unto Ephron; and Abraham weighed to Ephron the silver, which he had named in the audience of the sons of Heth, four hundred shekels of silver, current money with the merchant.

And*p the field of Ephron, which was in Machpelah, which was before Mamre, the field, and the cave which was therein, and all the trees that were in the field, that were in all the borders round about, were made sure
Unto*p Abraham for a possession in the presence of the children of Heth, before all that went in at the gate of his city.
And*p after this, Abraham buried Sarah his wife in the cave of the field of Machpelah before Mamre: the same is Hebron in the land of Canaan.
And*p the field, and the cave that is therein, were made sure unto Abraham for a possession of a buryingplace by the sons of Heth.
Genesis 24
And*p Abraham was old, and well stricken in age: and the Lord*s had blessed Abraham in all things.
And*p Abraham said unto his eldest servant of his house, that ruled over all that he had, Put, I pray thee, thy hand under my thigh:
And*p I will make thee swear by the Lord,*s the God of heaven, and the God of the earth, that thou shalt not take a wife unto my son of the daughters of the Canaanites, among whom I dwell:
But*p thou shalt go unto my country, and to my kindred, and take a wife unto my son Isaac.
And*p the servant said unto him, Peradventure the woman will not be willing to follow me unto this land: must I needs bring thy son again unto the land from whence thou camest?
And*p Abraham said unto him, Beware thou that thou bring not my son thither again.

The*p Lord*s God of heaven, which took me from my father's house, and from the land of my kindred, and which spake unto me, and that sware unto me, saying, Unto thy seed will I give this land; he shall send his angel before thee, and thou shalt take a wife unto my son from thence.
And*p if the woman will not be willing to follow thee, then thou shalt be clear from this my oath: only bring not my son thither again.
And*p the servant put his hand under the thigh of Abraham his master, and sware to him concerning that matter.
And*p the servant took ten camels of the camels of his master, and departed; for all the goods of his master were in his hand: and he arose, and went to Mesopotamia, unto the city of Nahor.
And*p he made his camels to kneel down without the city by a well of water at the time of the evening, even the time that women go out to draw water.
And*p he said, O Lord*s God of my master Abraham, I pray thee, send me good speed this day, and shew kindness unto my master Abraham.
Behold,*p I stand here by the well of water; and the daughters of the men of the city come out to draw water:

And*p let it come to pass, that the damsel to whom I shall say, Let down thy pitcher, I pray thee, that I may drink; and she shall say, Drink, and I will give thy camels drink also: let the same be she that thou hast appointed for thy servant Isaac; and thereby shall I know that thou hast shewed kindness unto my master.
And*p it came to pass, before he had done speaking, that, behold, Rebekah came out, who was born to Bethuel, son of Milcah, the wife of Nahor, Abraham's brother, with her pitcher upon her shoulder.
And*p the damsel was very fair to look upon, a virgin, neither had any man known her: and she went down to the well, and filled her pitcher, and came up.
And*p the servant ran to meet her, and said, Let me, I pray thee, drink a little water of thy pitcher.
And*p she said, Drink, my lord: and she hasted, and let down her pitcher upon her hand, and gave him drink.
And*p when she had done giving him drink, she said, I will draw water for thy camels also, until they have done drinking.
And*p she hasted, and emptied her pitcher into the trough, and ran again unto the well to draw water, and drew for all his camels.
And*p the man wondering at her held his peace, to wit whether the Lord*s had made his journey prosperous or not.
And*p it came to pass, as the camels had done drinking, that the man took a golden earring of half a shekel weight, and two bracelets for her hands of ten shekels weight of gold;
And*p said, Whose daughter art thou? tell me, I pray thee: is there room in thy father's house for us to lodge in?
And*p she said unto him, I am the daughter of Bethuel the son of Milcah, which she bare unto Nahor.
She*p said moreover unto him, We have both straw and provender enough, and room to lodge in.
And*p the man bowed down his head, and worshipped the Lord.*s

And*p he said, Blessed be the Lord*s God of my master Abraham, who hath not left destitute my master of his mercy and his truth: I being in the way, the Lord*s led me to the house of my master's brethren.
And*p the damsel ran, and told them of her mother's house these things.
And*p Rebekah had a brother, and his name was Laban: and Laban ran out unto the man, unto the well.

And*p it came to pass, when he saw the earring and bracelets upon his sister's hands, and when he heard the words of Rebekah his sister, saying, Thus spake the man unto me; that he came unto the man; and, behold, he stood by the camels at the well.
And*p he said, Come in, thou blessed of the Lord;*s wherefore standest thou without? for I have prepared the house, and room for the camels.
