And*p Pharaoh said unto Joseph, Forasmuch as God hath shewed thee all this, there is none so discreet and wise as thou art:
Thou*p shalt be over my house, and according unto thy word shall all my people be ruled: only in the throne will I be greater than thou.
And*p Pharaoh said unto Joseph, See, I have set thee over all the land of Egypt.
And*p Pharaoh took off his ring from his hand, and put it upon Joseph's hand, and arrayed him in vestures of fine linen, and put a gold chain about his neck;
And*p he made him to ride in the second chariot which he had; and they cried before him, Bow the knee: and he made him ruler over all the land of Egypt.
And*p Pharaoh said unto Joseph, I am Pharaoh, and without thee shall no man lift up his hand or foot in all the land of Egypt.
And*p Pharaoh called Joseph's name Zaphenath–paneah; and he gave him to wife Asenath the daughter of Poti–phera priest of On. And Joseph went out over all the land of Egypt.
And*p Joseph was thirty years old when he stood before Pharaoh king of Egypt. And Joseph went out from the presence of Pharaoh, and went throughout all the land of Egypt.
And*p in the seven plenteous years the earth brought forth by handfuls.

And*p he gathered up all the food of the seven years, which were in the land of Egypt, and laid up the food in the cities: the food of the field, which was round about every city, laid he up in the same.
And*p Joseph gathered corn as the sand of the sea, very much, until he left numbering; for it was without number.
And*p unto Joseph were born two sons before the years of famine came, which Asenath the daughter of Poti–phera priest of On bare unto him.
And*p Joseph called the name of the firstborn Manasseh: For God, said he, hath made me forget all my toil, and all my father's house.
And*p the name of the second called he Ephraim: For God hath caused me to be fruitful in the land of my affliction.
And*p the seven years of plenteousness, that was in the land of Egypt, were ended.
And*p the seven years of dearth began to come, according as Joseph had said: and the dearth was in all lands; but in all the land of Egypt there was bread.
And*p when all the land of Egypt was famished, the people cried to Pharaoh for bread: and Pharaoh said unto all the Egyptians, Go unto Joseph; what he saith to you, do.
And*p the famine was over all the face of the earth: And Joseph opened all the storehouses, and sold unto the Egyptians; and the famine waxed sore in the land of Egypt.
And*p all countries came into Egypt to Joseph for to buy corn; because that the famine was so sore in all lands.
Genesis 42
Now*p when Jacob saw that there was corn in Egypt, Jacob said unto his sons, Why do ye look one upon another?
And*p he said, Behold, I have heard that there is corn in Egypt: get you down thither, and buy for us from thence; that we may live, and not die.
And*p Joseph's ten brethren went down to buy corn in Egypt.
But*p Benjamin, Joseph's brother, Jacob sent not with his brethren; for he said, Lest peradventure mischief befall him.
And*p the sons of Israel came to buy corn among those that came: for the famine was in the land of Canaan.
And*p Joseph was the governor over the land, and he it was that sold to all the people of the land: and Joseph's brethren came, and bowed down themselves before him with their faces to the earth.

And*p Joseph saw his brethren, and he knew them, but made himself strange unto them, and spake roughly unto them; and he said unto them, Whence come ye? And they said, From the land of Canaan to buy food.
And*p Joseph knew his brethren, but they knew not him.
And*p Joseph remembered the dreams which he dreamed of them, and said unto them, Ye are spies; to see the nakedness of the land ye are come.
And*p they said unto him, Nay, my lord, but to buy food are thy servants come.
We*p are all one man's sons; we are true men, thy servants are no spies.
And*p he said unto them, Nay, but to see the nakedness of the land ye are come.
And*p they said, Thy servants are twelve brethren, the sons of one man in the land of Canaan; and, behold, the youngest is this day with our father, and one is not.
And*p Joseph said unto them, That is it that I spake unto you, saying, Ye are spies:
Hereby*p ye shall be proved: By the life of Pharaoh ye shall not go forth hence, except your youngest brother come hither.

Send*p one of you, and let him fetch your brother, and ye shall be kept in prison, that your words may be proved, whether there be any truth in you: or else by the life of Pharaoh surely ye are spies.
And*p he put them all together into ward three days.
And*p Joseph said unto them the third day, This do, and live; for I fear God:
If*p ye be true men, let one of your brethren be bound in the house of your prison: go ye, carry corn for the famine of your houses:
But*p bring your youngest brother unto me; so shall your words be verified, and ye shall not die. And they did so.

And*p they said one to another, We are verily guilty concerning our brother, in that we saw the anguish of his soul, when he besought us, and we would not hear; therefore is this distress come upon us.
And*p Reuben answered them, saying, Spake I not unto you, saying, Do not sin against the child; and ye would not hear? therefore, behold, also his blood is required.
And*p they knew not that Joseph understood them; for he spake unto them by an interpreter.
And*p he turned himself about from them, and wept; and returned to them again, and communed with them, and took from them Simeon, and bound him before their eyes.
Then*p Joseph commanded to fill their sacks with corn, and to restore every man's money into his sack, and to give them provision for the way: and thus did he unto them.
And*p they laded their asses with the corn, and departed thence.
And*p as one of them opened his sack to give his ass provender in the inn, he espied his money; for, behold, it was in his sack's mouth.

And*p he said unto his brethren, My money is restored; and, lo, it is even in my sack: and their heart failed them, and they were afraid, saying one to another, What is this that God hath done unto us?
And*p they came unto Jacob their father unto the land of Canaan, and told him all that befell unto them; saying,
The*p man, who is the lord of the land, spake roughly to us, and took us for spies of the country.
And*p we said unto him, We are true men; we are no spies:
We*p be twelve brethren, sons of our father; one is not, and the youngest is this day with our father in the land of Canaan.
And*p the man, the lord of the country, said unto us, Hereby shall I know that ye are true men; leave one of your brethren here with me, and take food for the famine of your households, and be gone:
And*p bring your youngest brother unto me: then shall I know that ye are no spies, but that ye are true men: so will I deliver you your brother, and ye shall traffick in the land.
And*p it came to pass as they emptied their sacks, that, behold, every man's bundle of money was in his sack: and when both they and their father saw the bundles of money, they were afraid.
And*p Jacob their father said unto them, Me have ye bereaved of my children: Joseph is not, and Simeon is not, and ye will take Benjamin away: all these things are against me.
And*p Reuben spake unto his father, saying, Slay my two sons, if I bring him not to thee: deliver him into my hand, and I will bring him to thee again.

And*p he said, My son shall not go down with you; for his brother is dead, and he is left alone: if mischief befall him by the way in the which ye go, then shall ye bring down my gray hairs with sorrow to the grave.
Genesis 43
And*p the famine was sore in the land.
And*p it came to pass, when they had eaten up the corn which they had brought out of Egypt, their father said unto them, Go again, buy us a little food.
And*p Judah spake unto him, saying, The man did solemnly protest unto us, saying, Ye shall not see my face, except your brother be with you.
If*p thou wilt send our brother with us, we will go down and buy thee food:
But*p if thou wilt not send him, we will not go down: for the man said unto us, Ye shall not see my face, except your brother be with you.
And*p Israel said, Wherefore dealt ye so ill with me, as to tell the man whether ye had yet a brother?

And*p they said, The man asked us straitly of our state, and of our kindred, saying, Is your father yet alive? have ye another brother? and we told him according to the tenor of these words: could we certainly know that he would say, Bring your brother down?
And*p Judah said unto Israel his father, Send the lad with me, and we will arise and go; that we may live, and not die, both we, and thou, and also our little ones.
I*p will be surety for him; of my hand shalt thou require him: if I bring him not unto thee, and set him before thee, then let me bear the blame for ever:
For*p except we had lingered, surely now we had returned this second time.

And*p their father Israel said unto them, If it must be so now, do this; take of the best fruits in the land in your vessels, and carry down the man a present, a little balm, and a little honey, spices, and myrrh, nuts, and almonds:
And*p take double money in your hand; and the money that was brought again in the mouth of your sacks, carry it again in your hand; peradventure it was an oversight:
Take*p also your brother, and arise, go again unto the man:
And*p God Almighty give you mercy before the man, that he may send away your other brother, and Benjamin. If I be bereaved of my children, I am bereaved.
And*p the men took that present, and they took double money in their hand, and Benjamin; and rose up, and went down to Egypt, and stood before Joseph.
And*p when Joseph saw Benjamin with them, he said to the ruler of his house, Bring these men home, and slay, and make ready; for these men shall dine with me at noon.
And*p the man did as Joseph bade; and the man brought the men into Joseph's house.

And*p the men were afraid, because they were brought into Joseph's house; and they said, Because of the money that was returned in our sacks at the first time are we brought in; that he may seek occasion against us, and fall upon us, and take us for bondmen, and our asses.
And*p they came near to the steward of Joseph's house, and they communed with him at the door of the house,
And*p said, O sir, we came indeed down at the first time to buy food:

And*p it came to pass, when we came to the inn, that we opened our sacks, and, behold, every man's money was in the mouth of his sack, our money in full weight: and we have brought it again in our hand.
And*p other money have we brought down in our hands to buy food: we cannot tell who put our money in our sacks.
And*p he said, Peace be to you, fear not: your God, and the God of your father, hath given you treasure in your sacks: I had your money. And he brought Simeon out unto them.
And*p the man brought the men into Joseph's house, and gave them water, and they washed their feet; and he gave their asses provender.
And*p they made ready the present against Joseph came at noon: for they heard that they should eat bread there.
And*p when Joseph came home, they brought him the present which was in their hand into the house, and bowed themselves to him to the earth.
And*p he asked them of their welfare, and said, Is your father well, the old man of whom ye spake? Is he yet alive?
And*p they answered, Thy servant our father is in good health, he is yet alive. And they bowed down their heads, and made obeisance.
And*p he lifted up his eyes, and saw his brother Benjamin, his mother's son, and said, Is this your younger brother, of whom ye spake unto me? And he said, God be gracious unto thee, my son.
And*p Joseph made haste; for his bowels did yearn upon his brother: and he sought where to weep; and he entered into his chamber, and wept there.
And*p he washed his face, and went out, and refrained himself, and said, Set on bread.

And*p they set on for him by himself, and for them by themselves, and for the Egyptians, which did eat with him, by themselves: because the Egyptians might not eat bread with the Hebrews; for that is an abomination unto the Egyptians.
And*p they sat before him, the firstborn according to his birthright, and the youngest according to his youth: and the men marvelled one at another.
And*p he took and sent messes unto them from before him: but Benjamin's mess was five times so much as any of theirs. And they drank, and were merry with him.
Genesis 44
And*p he commanded the steward of his house, saying, Fill the men's sacks with food, as much as they can carry, and put every man's money in his sack's mouth.
And*p put my cup, the silver cup, in the sack's mouth of the youngest, and his corn money. And he did according to the word that Joseph had spoken.
As*p soon as the morning was light, the men were sent away, they and their asses.

And*p when they were gone out of the city, and not yet far off, Joseph said unto his steward, Up, follow after the men; and when thou dost overtake them, say unto them, Wherefore have ye rewarded evil for good?
Is*p not this it in which my lord drinketh, and whereby indeed he divineth? ye have done evil in so doing.
And*p he overtook them, and he spake unto them these same words.
And*p they said unto him, Wherefore saith my lord these words? God forbid that thy servants should do according to this thing:
Behold,*p the money, which we found in our sacks' mouths, we brought again unto thee out of the land of Canaan: how then should we steal out of thy lord's house silver or gold?
With*p whomsoever of thy servants it be found, both let him die, and we also will be my lord's bondmen.
And*p he said, Now also let it be according unto your words: he with whom it is found shall be my servant; and ye shall be blameless.
Then*p they speedily took down every man his sack to the ground, and opened every man his sack.
And*p he searched, and began at the eldest, and left at the youngest: and the cup was found in Benjamin's sack.
Then*p they rent their clothes, and laded every man his ass, and returned to the city.
And*p Judah and his brethren came to Joseph's house; for he was yet there: and they fell before him on the ground.
And*p Joseph said unto them, What deed is this that ye have done? wot ye not that such a man as I can certainly divine?

And*p Judah said, What shall we say unto my lord? what shall we speak? or how shall we clear ourselves? God hath found out the iniquity of thy servants: behold, we are my lord's servants, both we, and he also with whom the cup is found.
And*p he said, God forbid that I should do so: but the man in whose hand the cup is found, he shall be my servant; and as for you, get you up in peace unto your father.
Then*p Judah came near unto him, and said, Oh my lord, let thy servant, I pray thee, speak a word in my lord's ears, and let not thine anger burn against thy servant: for thou art even as Pharaoh.
My*p lord asked his servants, saying, Have ye a father, or a brother?
And*p we said unto my lord, We have a father, an old man, and a child of his old age, a little one; and his brother is dead, and he alone is left of his mother, and his father loveth him.
And*p thou saidst unto thy servants, Bring him down unto me, that I may set mine eyes upon him.
And*p we said unto my lord, The lad cannot leave his father: for if he should leave his father, his father would die.
And*p thou saidst unto thy servants, Except your youngest brother come down with you, ye shall see my face no more.
And*p it came to pass when we came up unto thy servant my father, we told him the words of my lord.
And*p our father said, Go again, and buy us a little food.
And*p we said, We cannot go down: if our youngest brother be with us, then will we go down: for we may not see the man's face, except our youngest brother be with us.
And*p thy servant my father said unto us, Ye know that my wife bare me two sons:
And*p the one went out from me, and I said, Surely he is torn in pieces; and I saw him not since:
And*p if ye take this also from me, and mischief befall him, ye shall bring down my gray hairs with sorrow to the grave.
Now*p therefore when I come to thy servant my father, and the lad be not with us; seeing that his life is bound up in the lad's life;
It*p shall come to pass, when he seeth that the lad is not with us, that he will die: and thy servants shall bring down the gray hairs of thy servant our father with sorrow to the grave.
For*p thy servant became surety for the lad unto my father, saying, If I bring him not unto thee, then I shall bear the blame to my father for ever.
Now*p therefore, I pray thee, let thy servant abide instead of the lad a bondman to my lord; and let the lad go up with his brethren.
For*p how shall I go up to my father, and the lad be not with me? lest peradventure I see the evil that shall come on my father.
Genesis 45

Then*p Joseph could not refrain himself before all them that stood by him; and he cried, Cause every man to go out from me. And there stood no man with him, while Joseph made himself known unto his brethren.
And*p he wept aloud: and the Egyptians and the house of Pharaoh heard.
And*p Joseph said unto his brethren, I am Joseph; doth my father yet live? And his brethren could not answer him; for they were troubled at his presence.
And*p Joseph said unto his brethren, Come near to me, I pray you. And they came near. And he said, I am Joseph your brother, whom ye sold into Egypt.
Now*p therefore be not grieved, nor angry with yourselves, that ye sold me hither: for God did send me before you to preserve life.
For*p these two years hath the famine been in the land: and yet there are five years, in the which there shall neither be earing nor harvest.
And*p God sent me before you to preserve you a posterity in the earth, and to save your lives by a great deliverance.
So*p now it was not you that sent me hither, but God: and he hath made me a father to Pharaoh, and lord of all his house, and a ruler throughout all the land of Egypt.
Haste*p ye, and go up to my father, and say unto him, Thus saith thy son Joseph, God hath made me lord of all Egypt: come down unto me, tarry not:
And*p thou shalt dwell in the land of Goshen, and thou shalt be near unto me, thou, and thy children, and thy children's children, and thy flocks, and thy herds, and all that thou hast:
And*p there will I nourish thee; for yet there are five years of famine; lest thou, and thy household, and all that thou hast, come to poverty.
And,*p behold, your eyes see, and the eyes of my brother Benjamin, that it is my mouth that speaketh unto you.
And*p ye shall tell my father of all my glory in Egypt, and of all that ye have seen; and ye shall haste and bring down my father hither.
And*p he fell upon his brother Benjamin's neck, and wept; and Benjamin wept upon his neck.
Moreover*p he kissed all his brethren, and wept upon them: and after that his brethren talked with him.
And*p the fame thereof was heard in Pharaoh's house, saying, Joseph's brethren are come: and it pleased Pharaoh well, and his servants.
And*p Pharaoh said unto Joseph, Say unto thy brethren, This do ye; lade your beasts, and go, get you unto the land of Canaan;
And*p take your father and your households, and come unto me: and I will give you the good of the land of Egypt, and ye shall eat the fat of the land.
Now*p thou art commanded, this do ye; take you wagons out of the land of Egypt for your little ones, and for your wives, and bring your father, and come.
Also*p regard not your stuff; for the good of all the land of Egypt is yours.
And*p the children of Israel did so: and Joseph gave them wagons, according to the commandment of Pharaoh, and gave them provision for the way.
To*p all of them he gave each man changes of raiment; but to Benjamin he gave three hundred pieces of silver, and five changes of raiment.
And*p to his father he sent after this manner; ten asses laden with the good things of Egypt, and ten she asses laden with corn and bread and meat for his father by the way.
So*p he sent his brethren away, and they departed: and he said unto them, See that ye fall not out by the way.
And*p they went up out of Egypt, and came into the land of Canaan unto Jacob their father,
And*p told him, saying, Joseph is yet alive, and he is governor over all the land of Egypt. And Jacob's heart fainted, for he believed them not.
And*p they told him all the words of Joseph, which he had said unto them: and when he saw the wagons which Joseph had sent to carry him, the spirit of Jacob their father revived:
And*p Israel said, It is enough; Joseph my son is yet alive: I will go and see him before I die.
Genesis 46
And*p Israel took his journey with all that he had, and came to Beer–sheba, and offered sacrifices unto the God of his father Isaac.
And*p God spake unto Israel in the visions of the night, and said, Jacob, Jacob. And he said, Here am I.
And*p he said, I am God, the God of thy father: fear not to go down into Egypt; for I will there make of thee a great nation:
I*p will go down with thee into Egypt; and I will also surely bring thee up again: and Joseph shall put his hand upon thine eyes.
And*p Jacob rose up from Beer–sheba: and the sons of Israel carried Jacob their father, and their little ones, and their wives, in the wagons which Pharaoh had sent to carry him.
And*p they took their cattle, and their goods, which they had gotten in the land of Canaan, and came into Egypt, Jacob, and all his seed with him:
His*p sons, and his sons' sons with him, his daughters, and his sons' daughters, and all his seed brought he with him into Egypt.
And*p these are the names of the children of Israel, which came into Egypt, Jacob and his sons: Reuben, Jacob's firstborn.
And*p the sons of Reuben; Hanoch, and Pallu, and Hezron, and Carmi.
And*p the sons of Simeon; Jemuel, and Jamin, and Ohad, and Jachin, and Zohar, and Shaul the son of a Canaanitish woman.
And*p the sons of Levi; Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.
And*p the sons of Judah; Er, and Onan, and Shelah, and Pharez, and Zerah: but Er and Onan died in the land of Canaan. And the sons of Pharez were Hezron and Hamul.
And*p the sons of Issachar; Tola, and Phuvah, and Job, and Shimron.
And*p the sons of Zebulun; Sered, and Elon, and Jahleel.
These*p be the sons of Leah, which she bare unto Jacob in Paddan–aram, with his daughter Dinah: all the souls of his sons and his daughters were thirty and three.
And*p the sons of Gad; Ziphion, and Haggi, Shuni, and Ezbon, Eri, and Arodi, and Areli.
And*p the sons of Asher; Imnah, and Ishuah, and Ishvi, and Beriah, and Serah their sister: and the sons of Beriah; Heber, and Malchiel.
These*p are the sons of Zilpah, whom Laban gave to Leah his daughter, and these she bare unto Jacob, even sixteen souls.
The*p sons of Rachel Jacob's wife; Joseph, and Benjamin.
And*p unto Joseph in the land of Egypt were born Manasseh and Ephraim, which Asenath the daughter of Poti–phera priest of On bare unto him.
And*p the sons of Benjamin were Bela, and Becher, and Ashbel, Gera, and Naaman, Ehi, and Rosh, Muppim, and Huppim, and Ard.
These*p are the sons of Rachel, which were born to Jacob: all the souls were fourteen.
And*p the sons of Dan; Hushim.
And*p the sons of Naphtali; Jahzeel, and Guni, and Jezer, and Shillem.
These*p are the sons of Bilhah, which Laban gave unto Rachel his daughter, and she bare these unto Jacob: all the souls were seven.
All*p the souls that came with Jacob into Egypt, which came out of his loins, besides Jacob's sons' wives, all the souls were threescore and six;
And*p the sons of Joseph, which were born him in Egypt, were two souls: all the souls of the house of Jacob, which came into Egypt, were threescore and ten.
And*p he sent Judah before him unto Joseph, to direct his face unto Goshen; and they came into the land of Goshen.
And*p Joseph made ready his chariot, and went up to meet Israel his father, to Goshen, and presented himself unto him; and he fell on his neck, and wept on his neck a good while.
And*p Israel said unto Joseph, Now let me die, since I have seen thy face, because thou art yet alive.

And*p Joseph said unto his brethren, and unto his father's house, I will go up, and shew Pharaoh, and say unto him, My brethren, and my father's house, which were in the land of Canaan, are come unto me;
And*p the men are shepherds, for their trade hath been to feed cattle; and they have brought their flocks, and their herds, and all that they have.
And*p it shall come to pass, when Pharaoh shall call you, and shall say, What is your occupation?

That*p ye shall say, Thy servants' trade hath been about cattle from our youth even until now, both we, and also our fathers: that ye may dwell in the land of Goshen; for every shepherd is an abomination unto the Egyptians.
Genesis 47

Then*p Joseph came and told Pharaoh, and said, My father and my brethren, and their flocks, and their herds, and all that they have, are come out of the land of Canaan; and, behold, they are in the land of Goshen.
And*p he took some of his brethren, even five men, and presented them unto Pharaoh.
And*p Pharaoh said unto his brethren, What is your occupation? And they said unto Pharaoh, Thy servants are shepherds, both we, and also our fathers.

They*p said moreover unto Pharaoh, For to sojourn in the land are we come; for thy servants have no pasture for their flocks; for the famine is sore in the land of Canaan: now therefore, we pray thee, let thy servants dwell in the land of Goshen.
And*p Pharaoh spake unto Joseph, saying, Thy father and thy brethren are come unto thee:

The*p land of Egypt is before thee; in the best of the land make thy father and brethren to dwell; in the land of Goshen let them dwell: and if thou knowest any men of activity among them, then make them rulers over my cattle.
And*p Joseph brought in Jacob his father, and set him before Pharaoh: and Jacob blessed Pharaoh.
And*p Pharaoh said unto Jacob, How old art thou?

And*p Jacob said unto Pharaoh, The days of the years of my pilgrimage are an hundred and thirty years: few and evil have the days of the years of my life been, and have not attained unto the days of the years of the life of my fathers in the days of their pilgrimage.
And*p Jacob blessed Pharaoh, and went out from before Pharaoh.
And*p Joseph placed his father and his brethren, and gave them a possession in the land of Egypt, in the best of the land, in the land of Rameses, as Pharaoh had commanded.
And*p Joseph nourished his father, and his brethren, and all his father's household, with bread, according to their families.
And*p there was no bread in all the land; for the famine was very sore, so that the land of Egypt and all the land of Canaan fainted by reason of the famine.
And*p Joseph gathered up all the money that was found in the land of Egypt, and in the land of Canaan, for the corn which they bought: and Joseph brought the money into Pharaoh's house.
And*p when money failed in the land of Egypt, and in the land of Canaan, all the Egyptians came unto Joseph, and said, Give us bread: for why should we die in thy presence? for the money faileth.
And*p Joseph said, Give your cattle; and I will give you for your cattle, if money fail.

And*p they brought their cattle unto Joseph: and Joseph gave them bread in exchange for horses, and for the flocks, and for the cattle of the herds, and for the asses: and he fed them with bread for all their cattle for that year.

When*p that year was ended, they came unto him the second year, and said unto him, We will not hide it from my lord, how that our money is spent; my lord also hath our herds of cattle; there is not ought left in the sight of my lord, but our bodies, and our lands:

Wherefore*p shall we die before thine eyes, both we and our land? buy us and our land for bread, and we and our land will be servants unto Pharaoh: and give us seed, that we may live, and not die, that the land be not desolate.
And*p Joseph bought all the land of Egypt for Pharaoh; for the Egyptians sold every man his field, because the famine prevailed over them: so the land became Pharaoh's.
And*p as for the people, he removed them to cities from one end of the borders of Egypt even to the other end thereof.
Only*p the land of the priests bought he not; for the priests had a portion assigned them of Pharaoh, and did eat their portion which Pharaoh gave them: wherefore they sold not their lands.
Then*p Joseph said unto the people, Behold, I have bought you this day and your land for Pharaoh: lo, here is seed for you, and ye shall sow the land.

And*p it shall come to pass in the increase, that ye shall give the fifth part unto Pharaoh, and four parts shall be your own, for seed of the field, and for your food, and for them of your households, and for food for your little ones.
And*p they said, Thou hast saved our lives: let us find grace in the sight of my lord, and we will be Pharaoh's servants.
And*p Joseph made it a law over the land of Egypt unto this day, that Pharaoh should have the fifth part; except the land of the priests only, which became not Pharaoh's.
And*p Israel dwelt in the land of Egypt, in the country of Goshen; and they had possessions therein, and grew, and multiplied exceedingly.
And*p Jacob lived in the land of Egypt seventeen years: so the whole age of Jacob was an hundred forty and seven years.

And*p the time drew nigh that Israel must die: and he called his son Joseph, and said unto him, If now I have found grace in thy sight, put, I pray thee, thy hand under my thigh, and deal kindly and truly with me; bury me not, I pray thee, in Egypt:
But*p I will lie with my fathers, and thou shalt carry me out of Egypt, and bury me in their buryingplace. And he said, I will do as thou hast said.
And*p he said, Swear unto me. And he sware unto him. And Israel bowed himself upon the bed's head.
Genesis 48
And*p it came to pass after these things, that one told Joseph, Behold, thy father is sick: and he took with him his two sons, Manasseh and Ephraim.
And*p one told Jacob, and said, Behold, thy son Joseph cometh unto thee: and Israel strengthened himself, and sat upon the bed.
And*p Jacob said unto Joseph, God Almighty appeared unto me at Luz in the land of Canaan, and blessed me,
And*p said unto me, Behold, I will make thee fruitful, and multiply thee, and I will make of thee a multitude of people; and will give this land to thy seed after thee for an everlasting possession.
And*p now thy two sons, Ephraim and Manasseh, which were born unto thee in the land of Egypt before I came unto thee into Egypt, are mine; as Reuben and Simeon, they shall be mine.
And*p thy issue, which thou begettest after them, shall be thine, and shall be called after the name of their brethren in their inheritance.

And*p as for me, when I came from Paddan, Rachel died by me in the land of Canaan in the way, when yet there was but a little way to come unto Ephrath: and I buried her there in the way of Ephrath; the same is Beth–lehem.
And*p Israel beheld Joseph's sons, and said, Who are these?
And*p Joseph said unto his father, They are my sons, whom God hath given me in this place. And he said, Bring them, I pray thee, unto me, and I will bless them.
Now*p the eyes of Israel were dim for age, so that he could not see. And he brought them near unto him; and he kissed them, and embraced them.
And*p Israel said unto Joseph, I had not thought to see thy face: and, lo, God hath shewed me also thy seed.
And*p Joseph brought them out from between his knees, and he bowed himself with his face to the earth.
And*p Joseph took them both, Ephraim in his right hand toward Israel's left hand, and Manasseh in his left hand toward Israel's right hand, and brought them near unto him.
And*p Israel stretched out his right hand, and laid it upon Ephraim's head, who was the younger, and his left hand upon Manasseh's head, guiding his hands wittingly; for Manasseh was the firstborn.
And*p he blessed Joseph, and said, God, before whom my fathers Abraham and Isaac did walk, the God which fed me all my life long unto this day,

The*p Angel which redeemed me from all evil, bless the lads; and let my name be named on them, and the name of my fathers Abraham and Isaac; and let them grow into a multitude in the midst of the earth.
And*p when Joseph saw that his father laid his right hand upon the head of Ephraim, it displeased him: and he held up his father's hand, to remove it from Ephraim's head unto Manasseh's head.
And*p Joseph said unto his father, Not so, my father: for this is the firstborn; put thy right hand upon his head.

And*p his father refused, and said, I know it, my son, I know it: he also shall become a people, and he also shall be great: but truly his younger brother shall be greater than he, and his seed shall become a multitude of nations.
And*p he blessed them that day, saying, In thee shall Israel bless, saying, God make thee as Ephraim and as Manasseh: and he set Ephraim before Manasseh.
And*p Israel said unto Joseph, Behold, I die: but God shall be with you, and bring you again unto the land of your fathers.
Moreover*p I have given to thee one portion above thy brethren, which I took out of the hand of the Amorite with my sword and with my bow.
Genesis 49
And*p Jacob called unto his sons, and said, Gather yourselves together, that I may tell you that which shall befall you in the last days.
Gather*p yourselves together, and hear, ye sons of Jacob; and hearken unto Israel your father.
Reuben,*p thou art my firstborn, my might, and the beginning of my strength, the excellency of dignity, and the excellency of power:
Unstable*p as water, thou shalt not excel; because thou wentest up to thy father's bed; then defiledst thou it: he went up to my couch.
Simeon*p and Levi are brethren; instruments of cruelty are in their habitations.
O*p my soul, come not thou into their secret; unto their assembly, mine honour, be not thou united: for in their anger they slew a man, and in their selfwill they digged down a wall.
Cursed*p be their anger, for it was fierce; and their wrath, for it was cruel: I will divide them in Jacob, and scatter them in Israel.
Judah,*p thou art he whom thy brethren shall praise: thy hand shall be in the neck of thine enemies; thy father's children shall bow down before thee.
Judah*p is a lion's whelp: from the prey, my son, thou art gone up: he stooped down, he couched as a lion, and as an old lion; who shall rouse him up?
The*p sceptre shall not depart from Judah, nor a lawgiver from between his feet, until Shiloh come; and unto him shall the gathering of the people be.
Binding*p his foal unto the vine, and his ass's colt unto the choice vine; he washed his garments in wine, and his clothes in the blood of grapes:
His*p eyes shall be red with wine, and his teeth white with milk.
Zebulun*p shall dwell at the haven of the sea; and he shall be for an haven of ships; and his border shall be unto Zidon.
Issachar*p is a strong ass couching down between two burdens:
And*p he saw that rest was good, and the land that it was pleasant; and bowed his shoulder to bear, and became a servant unto tribute.
Dan*p shall judge his people, as one of the tribes of Israel.
Dan*p shall be a serpent by the way, an adder in the path, that biteth the horse heels, so that his rider shall fall backward.
I*p have waited for thy salvation, O Lord.*s
Gad,*p a troop shall overcome him: but he shall overcome at the last.
Out*p of Asher his bread shall be fat, and he shall yield royal dainties.
Naphtali*p is a hind let loose: he giveth goodly words.
Joseph*p is a fruitful bough, even a fruitful bough by a well; whose branches run over the wall:
The*p archers have sorely grieved him, and shot at him, and hated him:
But*p his bow abode in strength, and the arms of his hands were made strong by the hands of the mighty God of Jacob; (from thence is the shepherd, the stone of Israel:)

Even*p by the God of thy father, who shall help thee; and by the Almighty, who shall bless thee with blessings of heaven above, blessings of the deep that lieth under, blessings of the breasts, and of the womb:

The*p blessings of thy father have prevailed above the blessings of my progenitors unto the utmost bound of the everlasting hills: they shall be on the head of Joseph, and on the crown of the head of him that was separate from his brethren.
Benjamin*p shall ravin as a wolf: in the morning he shall devour the prey, and at night he shall divide the spoil.
All*p these are the twelve tribes of Israel: and this is it that their father spake unto them, and blessed them; every one according to his blessing he blessed them.
And*p he charged them, and said unto them, I am to be gathered unto my people: bury me with my fathers in the cave that is in the field of Ephron the Hittite,
In*p the cave that is in the field of Machpelah, which is before Mamre, in the land of Canaan, which Abraham bought with the field of Ephron the Hittite for a possession of a buryingplace.
There*p they buried Abraham and Sarah his wife; there they buried Isaac and Rebekah his wife; and there I buried Leah.
The*p purchase of the field and of the cave that is therein was from the children of Heth.
And*p when Jacob had made an end of commanding his sons, he gathered up his feet into the bed, and yielded up the ghost, and was gathered unto his people.
Genesis 50
And*p Joseph fell upon his father's face, and wept upon him, and kissed him.
And*p Joseph commanded his servants the physicians to embalm his father: and the physicians embalmed Israel.
And*p forty days were fulfilled for him; for so are fulfilled the days of those which are embalmed: and the Egyptians mourned for him threescore and ten days.
And*p when the days of his mourning were past, Joseph spake unto the house of Pharaoh, saying, If now I have found grace in your eyes, speak, I pray you, in the ears of Pharaoh, saying,

My*p father made me swear, saying, Lo, I die: in my grave which I have digged for me in the land of Canaan, there shalt thou bury me. Now therefore let me go up, I pray thee, and bury my father, and I will come again.
And*p Pharaoh said, Go up, and bury thy father, according as he made thee swear.
And*p Joseph went up to bury his father: and with him went up all the servants of Pharaoh, the elders of his house, and all the elders of the land of Egypt,
And*p all the house of Joseph, and his brethren, and his father's house: only their little ones, and their flocks, and their herds, they left in the land of Goshen.
And*p there went up with him both chariots and horsemen: and it was a very great company.
And*p they came to the threshingfloor of Atad, which is beyond Jordan, and there they mourned with a great and very sore lamentation: and he made a mourning for his father seven days.

And*p when the inhabitants of the land, the Canaanites, saw the mourning in the floor of Atad, they said, This is a grievous mourning to the Egyptians: wherefore the name of it was called Abel–mizraim, which is beyond Jordan.
And*p his sons did unto him according as he commanded them:

For*p his sons carried him into the land of Canaan, and buried him in the cave of the field of Machpelah, which Abraham bought with the field for a possession of a buryingplace of Ephron the Hittite, before Mamre.
And*p Joseph returned into Egypt, he, and his brethren, and all that went up with him to bury his father, after he had buried his father.
And*p when Joseph's brethren saw that their father was dead, they said, Joseph will peradventure hate us, and will certainly requite us all the evil which we did unto him.
And*p they sent a messenger unto Joseph, saying, Thy father did command before he died, saying,

So*p shall ye say unto Joseph, Forgive, I pray thee now, the trespass of thy brethren, and their sin; for they did unto thee evil: and now, we pray thee, forgive the trespass of the servants of the God of thy father. And Joseph wept when they spake unto him.
And*p his brethren also went and fell down before his face; and they said, Behold, we be thy servants.
And*p Joseph said unto them, Fear not: for am I in the place of God?
But*p as for you, ye thought evil against me; but God meant it unto good, to bring to pass, as it is this day, to save much people alive.
Now*p therefore fear ye not: I will nourish you, and your little ones. And he comforted them, and spake kindly unto them.
And*p Joseph dwelt in Egypt, he, and his father's house: and Joseph lived an hundred and ten years.
And*p Joseph saw Ephraim's children of the third generation: the children also of Machir the son of Manasseh were brought up upon Joseph's knees.
And*p Joseph said unto his brethren, I die: and God will surely visit you, and bring you out of this land unto the land which he sware to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob.
And*p Joseph took an oath of the children of Israel, saying, God will surely visit you, and ye shall carry up my bones from hence.
So*p Joseph died, being an hundred and ten years old: and they embalmed him, and he was put in a coffin in Egypt.
